Pasient spør: "Kan stress forverre TMD og øresymptomer?"
Ja. Stress er en kjent trigger for tannpressing og kjevespenning, som igjen kan forverre både TMD og assosierte øresymptomer. Stressmestring er derfor en viktig del av behandlingen.
You are a clinical communication assistant for chiropractors. Answer patient questions clearly and empathetically using correct medical terminology.
Patient asks: "Do I need an MRI or X-ray?"

Rarely for typical headache. Imaging is primarily relevant for alarm symptoms (red flags) or abnormal findings on examination. It's important to know that MRI often shows age-related changes that don't explain the pain.
You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Describe symptoms for Whiplash.

Symptoms

 Main symptoms

 Neck pain and stiffness - 62-100% (the most common symptom)

 Headache - 60-88%, often originating from the neck

 Shoulder and upper back stiffness - approx. 72%

 Fatigue - 70-80%

 Dizziness - 25-50% (up to 85% in some studies)

 Concentration difficulties - approx. 41%

 Delayed symptom onset is common

 Symptoms don't need to appear immediately. Many experience delayed onset from 12 hours to several
 days after the accident. This delay of 12-72 hours is characteristic and is due in part to adrenaline
 and endorphins masking pain in the acute phase.

Patient asks: "Can I continue to throw?"

With proper treatment, many can return to throwing. Focus on mobility, strength
 and optimized technique. Gradual return to full activity.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Cortisone Injection in Shoulder: Friend or Foe?.

What is Cortisone and How Does it Work?: Cortisone (corticosteroids) are synthetic versions of cortisol - a hormone the body produces itself.
 When injected locally, it has a powerful anti-inflammatory effect.

The Benefits of Cortisone: Cortisone has its place in treating shoulder problems. Here are situations where it can be useful
The Drawbacks and Risks: Research in recent years has shown that cortisone isn't as innocent as previously thought. Here's what
 you should know
When Should You Avoid Cortisone?: Based on current knowledge, there are some situations where cortisone is generally not recommended
Alternatives to Cortisone: There are several effective alternatives that often provide better long-term results
If You Choose Cortisone: If cortisone is the right choice for you, there are some things that increase the chance of a good
 result

Behandlingsalternativer

 

 
 Krystallsyke (BPPV)

 Reposisjonsmanøvre (Epley/Semont) har 80-90% suksessrate. Mange opplever betydelig bedring etter 1-3 behandlinger.

 

 
 Nakkerelatert svimmelhet

 Manuell behandling, leddkorreksjoner og spesifikke øvelser. Typisk 4-8 behandlinger over noen uker.

 

 
 Vestibularisnevritt

 Vestibulær rehabilitering og kompensasjonstrening. 4-12 ukers program ved mer sammensatte tilstander.

 

 
 Ménières sykdom

 Livsstilsendringer, medisiner og spesialistoppfølging.

 

 Vestibulær rehabilitering

 Vestibulær rehabilitering er spesialisert fysioterapi

Forklar Akutt Skadehåndtering for en pasient.

Tråkket over på fotballbanen. Vrukket ankelen på tur i marka. Kjente et rykk i låret under sprinten. De fleste har lært RICE - hvile, is, kompresjon og elevasjon - men dette prinsippet er utdatert. I 2015 trakk Dr. Gabe Mirkin, mannen som lanserte RICE i 1978, tilbake sin egen anbefaling. Total hvile og overdreven bruk av is kan forsinke kroppens naturlige tilheling (Mirkin, 2015). Her forklarer vi POLICE-prinsippet og det nyeste rammeverket PEACE & LOVE - slik at du vet nøyaktig hva du skal gjøre de første 72 timene etter en akutt idrettsskade .

- H82 for BPPV
- N89 for vestibulær migrene
- K99 for kardiovaskulær årsak

Beskriv Hva er triggerpunkter? for Triggerpunkter i Arm og Underarm.

Hva er triggerpunkter?

 

 Triggerpunkter er hypersensitive områder i muskelfibre - ofte beskrevet som "knuter" eller "strammer". Når du trykker på et triggerpunkt, gir det karakteristisk smerte, og ofte også referred pain - smerte som stråler ut til andre områder.

 Det finnes to hovedtyper:

 
 Aktive triggerpunkter Gir symptomer

 Gir spontan smerte og referred pain. Kan forstyrre søvn og påvirke daglig funksjon.

 

 
 Latente triggerpunkter

 Omme bare ved trykk. Kan begrense bevegelighet og svekke muskelen, men gir ikke spontan smerte.

 

 
 
 85-95%
 av kroniske smerter
 

 
 70%
 av tennisalbue-pasienter
 

 
 54%
 av hodepinepasienter

Skriv subjektiv del av SOAP-notat for en pasient med Fottrening som virker: Øvelser for sterkere fåtter.

Fåttene dine inneholder 26 knokler, 33 ledd og over 100 muskler, sener og ligamenter. Likevel ignorerer de fleste treningsprogrammer foten fullstendig. Resultatet? Svake fåtter som kompenseres med stive sko og innleggssåler.

 Den gode nyheten: Forskning viser at målrettet fottrening kan Øke fotstyrken med opptil 57%, redusere skader med over halvparten, og lindre smerter bedre enn tradisjonelle behandlinger. Og det beste er at Øvelsene er enkle og kan gjøres hjemme.

Clinical summary of Chiropractor vs Naprapat: What Is the Difference and Who Should You Choose?.

Key takeaways

 Both are primary contact practitioners -- no referral needed

 Chiropractor: Authorised since 1989, can issue sick leave and order MRI/X-ray

 Naprapat: Authorised since 2022, cannot issue sick leave or order imaging

 Education: Chiropractor 5-6 years, naprapat 4 years

 Treatment duration: Chiropractor often shorter, naprapat often longer

Describe treatment options for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

Treatments NOT recommended

 

 Based on systematic reviews and international guidelines, the following are discouraged for TMD:

 
 Discouraged treatments

 
 Occlusal adjustment (bite grinding): Cochrane review found no difference from placebo

 Orthodontics to "prevent" TMD: Systematic reviews show "Neutral effect" - neither prevents nor causes

 Surgical interventions as first choice: BMJ guidelines (2023) strongly recommend against irreversible treatments

 
 

 INfORM/IADR (2025) summarizes: "Dental and surgical techniques to correct occlusion are not supported" as treatment for TMD.

Clinical summary of Dry Needling at the Chiropractor: What It Is, Effectiveness and Side Effects.

Key takeaways

 What: Thin, sterile needles are inserted into trigger points in the musculature to release tension and reduce pain

 Not acupuncture: Based on Western anatomy and neurophysiology, not meridians or energy pathways

 Evidence: Low to moderate evidence for short-term pain relief up to 12 weeks (Gattie et al. 2017). Long-term effect uncertain

 Safe: Serious complications extremely rare, approx. 1 per million treatments (Brady et al. 2014)

 Best results: When dry needling is combined with exercises and other treatment

Patient asks: "Is chiropractic better than physiotherapy?"

Not better — often equivalent. Studies show comparable results for back and neck pain. The approaches overlap, and the choice depends on what suits you best. The combination of manual therapy and exercise produces the best results regardless of practitioner.

Describe Who is Affected? for Flat Back (Hypokyphosis).

Who is Affected?

 

 Hypokyphosis and Straight Back Syndrome have a clear age pattern. A review of 114 SBS patients showed
 that 95% were under 40 years, and 60% were between 20 and 40 years (Jiang & Li, referenced in Kong et al.,
 World Journal of Cardiology, 2023). The condition appears to become rarer with age.

 
 Groups with increased prevalence

 
 Gymnasts and ballet dancers more often develop flat back, probably due to repeated
 extension movements. A study of 33 ballet dancers found hypokyphosis in 9.1% (MDPI, 2021).

 Patients with idiopathic scoliosis often have concurrent reduced kyphosis as part
 of the three-dimensional spinal deformity.

 After spinal surgery: Historically, Harrington rods were known to flatten the back.
 Modern techniques provide better control, but studies still show that 31% of scoliosis surgery
 patients have reduced kyphosis at follow-up (PMC, 2013).

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 26 år mann. Korsryggsmerte siste 5 måneder. Morgenstivhet varierer 30-50 min. Noen dager bedre enn andre. Usikker om aktivitet hjelper eller forverrer. Ingen ekstraartikulære symptomer.

MONITORÉR: Uavklart ryggsmerte — grensetilfelle mellom mekanisk og inflammatorisk. Varierende morgenstivhet rundt 45-minuttersgrensen og usikkert aktivitetsmønster. Alder og varighet passer inflammatorisk, men mangler typisk mønster. Blodprøver (CRP, HLA-B27) som screening. Re-evaluér etter 4 uker.

Beskriv diagnostikk for Hekseskudd.

Diagnostikk

 Diagnosen hekseskudd stilles primært gjennom sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. Bildediagnostikk er som regel ikke nødvendig ved ukompliserte tilfeller.

 Hva skjer ved undersøkelsen?

 Sykehistorie: Hvordan og når smertene startet, smertens karakter og lokalisasjon

 Funksjonsundersøkelse: Vurdering av bevegelighet, holdning og smerteutløsende bevegelser

 Nevrologisk screening: Utelukke nerveaffeksjon ved utstrålende symptomer

 Røde flagg-vurdering: Systematisk gjennomgang for å utelukke alvorlig underliggende sykdom

 Når er bildediagnostikk aktuelt?

 MR eller røntgen er sjelden nødvendig ved første konsultasjon. Det er aktuelt ved mistanke om alvorlig underliggende sykdom ( røde flagg ), ved vedvarende symptomer over 6-8 uker uten bedring, eller ved progressive nevrologiske utfall.

Skriv subjektiv del av SOAP-notat for en pasient med Migrene: Alt du trenger å vite.

Du merker det kommer. Kanskje ser du flimrende lysshow i synsfeltet, eller kjenner en rar tretthet og matbehov. Så slær det til: en bankende, pulserende smerte som gjør det umulig å tenke klart. Lyset fra vinduet føles som kniver, og lyden av tv-en er uutholdelig.

 Hvis dette hØres kjent ut, er du ikke alene. Migrene rammer rundt 12-13% av alle nordmenn - det betyr at omtrent en av å tte voksne opplever dette (HUNT-studiene). Kvinner er tre ganger så utsatt som menn.

 Men hva er egentlig migre

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Fottrening som virker: øvelser for sterkere føtter.

Hvorfor fottrening?: Fottrening er ikke bare for idrettsutøvere eller de med eksisterende problemer. Forskningen viser imponerende resultater for alle som investerer tid i fotene sine
Hva sier forskningen?: De siste ørene har det kommet flere banebrytende studier som dokumenterer effekten av fottrening
Øvelse 1: Short Foot (Kortfot): Short foot er den mest fundamentale øvelsen for fothelse. Den aktiverer de intrinsiske musklene som støtter fotbuen - musklene som ofte blir «sløtt av» etter ørevis i støttende sko.

Øvelse 2: Tåspreading: Etter ørevis i trange sko har mange mistet evnen til å spre tårne aktivt. Tåspreading reaktiverer abduktørmusklene og forbedrer stabiliteten i forfoten.

Øvelse 3: Tågriping (Towel Curls): En klassisk øvelse som styrker flexormusklene under foten. Denne øvelsen er spesielt nyttig for de med plantar fascitt.

Øvelse 4: Hælhev med fokus: Hælhev (calf raises) er en kjent øvelse, men med riktig fokus blir den en kraftfull fottrening. NØkkelen er å holde fotbuen aktiv gjennom hele bevegelsen.

Øvelse 5: Ett-bens balanse: Funksjonell trening som utfordrer hele foten dynamisk. Denne øvelsen bygger bro mellom isolerte fotøvelser og daglig funksjon.

Forslag til ukentlig program: Her er et enkelt program du kan følge. Tilpass etter eget nivå og tid tilgjengelig.

Barfotgåing og minimalistsko: Liverpool-studien (Curtis 2021) viste at 6 måneder med minimalistsko økte fotstyrken med 57% - uten spesifikke øvelser . Bare ved å la foten jobbe naturlig.

Når kan du forvente resultater?: Fottrening krever tålmodighet, men resultatene kommer gradvis
Røde flagg - når du bør oppsøke lege: Mild muskelømhet etter fottrening er normalt, spesielt i starten. Men skarp smerte, nummenhet eller hevelse er tegn på at du bør ta en pause og eventuelt søke vurdering.

Describe How Text Neck Affects the Jaw for Text Neck and Jaw Pain: How Mobile Use Affects the Jaw.

How Text Neck Affects the Jaw

 

 The connection between forward head posture and jaw problems is well documented:

 
 1. Biomechanical Change

 When the head moves forward:

 
 The lower jaw is pulled backward and down by gravity

 The jaw muscles must work to keep the mouth closed

 The jaw joint is loaded asymmetrically

 The posterior part of the joint is compressed

 
 

 
 2. Muscular Compensation

 
 Masseter and temporalis are activated unnecessarily

 Constant low-level tension leads to fatigue

 Increased risk of trigger points

 Tension headaches in the temples

 
 

 
 3. Nerve Connections

 
 The trigeminocervical complex connects neck and jaw

 Tight neck muscles can cause referred pain to the jaw

 Suboccipital tension affects jaw muscles reflexively

 
 

 
 Research Confirms the Connection

 Studies show that 70-90% of TMD patients have concurrent neck problems, and that treatment of the neck often improves jaw symptoms - even without direct jaw treatment.

Beskriv Undersøkelsesmetoder i kontekst av Eagle Syndrom.

Undersøkelsesmetoder

 
 Intraoral palpasjon: Forsiktig palpasjon av tonsilleområdet kan avdekke hard spiss

 Provokasjon: Smerter ved rotasjon av hodet, svelging

 Lidokaintest: Injeksjon av lokalanestesi i tonsilleområdet kan midlertidig lindre symptomene

 
 

 Bildediagnostikk

 
 
 
 Modalitet
 Beskrivelse
 
 
 
 
 CT med 3D-rekonstruksjon
 Gullstandard - visualiserer lengde, vinkel og relasjon til omliggende strukturer
 
 
 Panoramarøntgen
 Kan vise forlenget styloid, men undervurderer ofte lengden
 
 
 CT-angiografi
 Ved mistanke om vaskulær kompresjon
 
 
 

 Diagnostiske kriterier

 Diagnosen stilles basert på:

 
 Karakteristiske symptomer

 Radiologisk påvist forlenget/forkalket styloid eller stylohyoid-ligament

 Utelukkelse av andre Årsaker

 Eventuelt positiv respons på diagnostisk blokade

 
 

 
 
 
 6
 Differensialdiagnoser

 

 Eagle syndrom må skilles fra flere andre tilstander:

 
 Viktige differensialdiagnoser

 
 Temporomandibular dysfunksjon (TMD)

 Glossopharyngeal nevralgi

 Trigeminal nevralgi

 Cervikal spondylose

 Kronisk tonsillitt

 HalstumØrer

 Carotisdisseksjon

 Migrene

 Giant cell arteritt (eldre pasienter)

Patient asks: "What is ankylosing spondylitis?"

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects
 the spine and SI joints. Over time, the inflammation can lead to stiffening of the spine.

Describe Motion-Triggered MdDS (Most Common) in the context of Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS).

Motion-Triggered MdDS (Most Common)

 
 Cruise or boat travel - by far the most common trigger

 Air travel

 Long car journey or train ride

 Elevator ride or walking on a pier

 
 

 Temporary "mal de debarquement" after sea travel occurs in 73-86% of people, even among experienced sailors. Longer trips and rough seas can increase the risk, but the duration of exposure does not seem to determine severity.

 
 Spontaneous/Non-Motion-Triggered MdDS (Rarer)

 
 Hormonal changes - studies show that ~44% had symptom onset during perimenopause or menopause

 Psychological stress or major life events

 Surgical procedures

 Head injury

 Without identifiable cause

 
 

 Who Is Affected?

 MdDS has a clear demographic profile:

 
 Women make up 80-90% of cases

 Average onset age: 43-50 years

 Sex ratio: Women:men approximately 9:1

 Migraine: People with migraine have increased risk of developing MdDS. These patients may also experience vestibular migraine

 
 

 
 
 3
 Symptoms

 

 Main Symptoms

 The characteristic symptom is a persistent oscillating dizziness - a sensation of:

 
 Rocking

 Swaying motion

 Bobbing (up-down movement)

 
 Symptoms are present continuously or most of the day. They are not accompanied by the spinning sensation (vertigo) seen in BPPV (crystal disease).

 Associated Symptoms

 Many with MdDS develop additional symptoms:

 
 Spatial disorientation

 Fatigue

 Intolerance to visual motion (busy environments, escalators)

 Headache - often migraine-like

 Anxiety and depression

 Cognitive difficulties ("brain fog")

 Concentration problems

 Sleep difficulties

 Neck and back pain

 

 
 The Paradox: Better in Motion

 An important characteristic of MdDS is that symptoms often improve when in passive motion - such as driving a car or sitting on a train. But symptoms return - and may temporarily worsen - when the motion stops.

 This distinguishes MdDS from PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness), where symptoms typically worsen with motion.

Differential diagnoses for Text Neck and Phone Neck?

Prolonged screen use in forward-bent position (most common)

 The clearly most common cause of text neck is simply the time spent with the head bent over the phone, tablet or PC. A meta-analysis from 2025 found that excessive smartphone use gives 2.34 times higher risk of neck pain. Among office workers, the risk was even higher - 6 times increased risk .

Poor workplace ergonomics

 Screen placed too low, chair without support, or lack of height adjustment contributes to the neck being held in unfavorable positions hour after hour.

Lack of breaks and movement

 Static work without micro-breaks overloads the neck musculature. Health guidelines recommend varied activity, different work positions and frequent micro-breaks.

How is Chronic Dizziness and PPPD diagnosed?

The Five Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2017)

 

 
 1. Duration

 Dizziness, unsteadiness or non-rotational vertigo present most days for at least three months

 

 
 2. Aggravating Factors

 Symptoms worsen with upright posture, active or passive movement, and visually complex or moving stimuli

 

 
 3. Triggering Event

 The condition started after an acute vestibular disorder, other medical illness, or psychological stress

 

 
 4. Symptom Impact

 Symptoms cause significant distress or functional impairment

 

 
 5. No Better Explanation

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another disease

Describe diagnosis for L5.

Diagnosis

 Clinical Examination

 Straight Leg Raise (Lasegue's test): Positive with pain down back of thigh/calf when leg raised between 30-70 degrees. Sensitivity: 72-97%, Specificity: 11-66%. Most sensitive for pain between 30-45 degrees.

 Crossed Lasegue: Pain in the affected leg when the healthy leg is raised. Lower sensitivity (23-42%), but high specificity (85-100%). Suggests larger, central herniation when positive.

 Achilles reflex: Reduced or absent with S1 involvement. 91% specificity.

 Imaging

 MRI is the gold standard and shows herniation degree, nerve root compression and any other findings. Important to remember: MRI often shows findings that don't explain the symptoms. A meta-analysis of asymptomatic people found disc bulging in 10-81%, protrusions in 3-63%. Clinical examination is therefore often more important than the images.

 De fleste med episodisk spenningshodepine får god lindring med behandling. Manuell behandling gir ofte effekt innen 4-8 uker.

 Realistiske forventninger
 Behandling reduserer typisk hodepinefrekvens og intensitet, men eliminerer ikke nødvendigvis alle hodepiner

 Tilbakefall er vanlig, særlig ved vedvarende risikofaktorer som dårlig holdning eller stress

Explain postural exercises for Neck Exercises Home Program.

Postural exercises

 Postural exercises correct the forward-leaning position that many develop from prolonged screen work and phone use . These exercises train the body to maintain a more neutral position throughout the day.

 Wall angel

 Stand with your back against a wall — heels, buttocks, upper back and back of head against the wall

 Raise your arms to a "W" position (elbows bent 90 degrees, forearms against wall)

 Slowly slide your arms up to a "Y" position while maintaining wall contact

 Lower back to "W"

 Dosage: 10 repetitions

 Effect: Corrects thoracic kyphosis and forward head posture.

 Bruegger's position

 Sit on the edge of a chair with feet slightly wider than hip width

 Let your arms hang at your sides, rotate them outward (palms facing forward)

 Squeeze your shoulder blades together and lift your sternum

 Gently tuck your chin (chin tuck)

 Dosage: Hold 10-30 seconds, 5-10 repetitions throughout the workday

 Tip: Bruegger's position is perfect as a counter-exercise after prolonged sitting and can be done every other hour at the office.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How do I know if my rib is broken or just dislocated?

 The most important clue is the trauma history. With a fracture, you remember
 exactly what happened - a fall, a blow, an accident. With dislocation, the history is often more vague.
 The intensity is also different - fractures typically cause more intense pain that makes it difficult to
 take deep breaths. A clinical examination can usually distinguish between the conditions.

 

 
 Do I need an X-ray to know if my rib is broken?

 Not necessarily. Norwegian guidelines state that rib fractures are primarily a
 clinical diagnosis. X-rays also have low accuracy (about 50%) and rarely change treatment for
 uncomplicated fractures. Imaging becomes important when complications are suspected or with serious
 trauma.

 

 
 Can I exercise with rib dislocation?

 Yes, but adapt the activity. Avoid exercises that provoke pain, especially heavy
 rotational movements. Light activity like walking is often perfectly fine. After treatment, you can
 gradually resume normal training.

 

 
 How long am I on sick leave with rib fractures?

 It depends on the nature of the work. For physically demanding work, 4-6 weeks may
 be necessary. For sedentary work, many can return earlier, but with adjustments. As a chiropractor, I
 can write sick leave for up to 12 weeks.

 

 
 Why does it hurt so much to breathe?

 The nerves that run along the ribs (intercostal nerves) become irritated with both
 fractures a...

Provide a structured clinical overview of Exercises for Stiff Neck.

Why does the neck become stiff?: Neck stiffness in office workers results from several interacting factors. Prolonged sitting puts the neck under strain it is not designed for.

Mobilization exercises: Always start with mobilization to warm up the joints and restore range of motion. These exercises are gentle enough to be performed even on bad days.

Stretching exercises: Stretching addresses the tight muscles that hold the neck in a stiff position. Ylinen et al. (2003) found that stretching alone produced 59% pain reduction — useful as a supplement, but strengthening should be prioritized for lasting effect.

Strengthening exercises: Strengthening exercises provide the most lasting effect against stiff neck. A 2024 systematic review confirms that strength training produces significant reduction in pain intensity and disability in office workers with neck problems.

5-minute office program: This program is designed to be done discreetly at your desk. No colleagues will notice you are exercising. Set an alarm or link it to regular events in your workday.

5-minute morning routine: Many office workers wake up with a stiff neck that persists throughout the day. This short morning routine loosens the stiffness before you get to work and provides a better start to the workday.

Symptomer

 

 De typiske symptomene ved occipital nevralgi er karakteristiske og skiller seg fra andre hodepinetyper:

 Smertekarakter

 
 Stikkende, skytende eller brennende smerte

 Ofte beskrevet som "elektriske støt"

 Starter ved nakke-/bakhodegrensen og stråler oppover mot bakhodet

 Kan nå helt frem til pannen eller bak Øyet

 Vanligvis ensidig, men kan våre bilateral

 

 Anfallsmønster

 
 Anfall av intens smerte som varer sekunder til minutter

 Kan ha underliggende verkende smerte mellom anfallene

 Utløses ofte av hodebevegelser eller berØring av hodebunnen

 

 Ledsagende symptomer

 
 Allodyni: Hodebunnen blir Øm å berØre - selv lett berØring kan gjøre vondt

 Nummenhet eller prikking i hodebunnen

 Smerter ved å børste hØret eller legge hodet på puten

 Lysfålsomhet (mindre vanlig enn ved migrene)

 

 
 Diagnostisk test

 Ved occipital nevralgi er det typisk Ømhet ved palpasjon over occipitalnervens utgangssted (ca. midtveis mellom Øret og nakkevirvlene, ved bakhodets nedre grense). Trykk her kan reprodusere eller forsterke symptomene.

Describe causes and risk factors for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Overload is the main cause

 PHT typically develops over time due to
 Too much, too fast - rapid increase in training load

 Compression + stretch - the tendon is squeezed against the bone with hip flexion

 Repetitive loading - running, cycling, rowing

 Prolonged sitting - constant pressure on the tendon

 Typical triggering activities

 Activities that increase risk

 Hill running - especially uphill

 Interval training - high speed demands

 Cycling - especially with low saddle height

 Yoga and Pilates - lots of hamstring stretching

 Rowing - repetitive hip flexion under load

 Biomechanical risk factors

 Weak gluteal muscles - gluteus must compensate (see also gluteal tendinopathy )

 Poor pelvic control - too much movement in the pelvis

 Stiff thoracic spine - compensatory movement in the pelvis

 Overstriding - too long stride length when running

Patient asks: "What is the difference between groin strain and sports hernia?"

Groin strain is a muscle injury in the adductors with often sudden onset and localized tenderness. Sports hernia (athletic pubalgia) is a weakness in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal without a visible bulge, often with gradual onset and pain with coughing/sneezing. MRI can distinguish between these.

Describe Myth 1: "Dizziness and vertigo are the same thing" in the context of Dizziness: Myths Debunked and Real Help Available.

Myth 1: "Dizziness and vertigo are the same thing"

 Fact: Dizziness is a broad term that encompasses several different experiences: feeling unstable, lightheaded, about to faint, or that the world is spinning around. Vertigo is a specific subtype where you experience a sensation of rotation.

 Distinguishing between these is important for finding the right cause and treatment. Vertigo often points to the vestibular system, while other types of dizziness can be caused by anything from blood pressure drops to neck problems or anxiety.

What causes SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and risk factors

 

 SLAP lesions can occur in several ways:

 Acute injury

 
 Fall on outstretched arm: Compression forces push the upper arm bone up against the
 labrum

 Direct trauma: Blow to the shoulder

 Sudden pull: Heavy lifting or jerking of the arm

 

 Overload (most common)

 
 
 Repetitive overhead activity

 Main cause
 

 Throwing movements and overhead sports expose the biceps attachment to repeated pulling forces. Over
 time, this can lead to SLAP lesion. Common in:

 
 Handball players (see thrower's shoulder)

 Volleyball players

 Baseball pitchers

 Swimmers

 Tennis players

 
 

 Risk factors

 
 Overhead sports, especially throwing sports

 Age 20-40 years for traumatic lesions

 Age over 40 for degenerative changes (type I)

 Glenohumeral internal rotation deficit (GIRD)

 Weak scapula control

 Previous shoulder instability

 

 
 Important perspective

 Many have SLAP lesions on MRI without symptoms. A study found that up to 55% of asymptomatic
 shoulders in people over 45 years had labrum changes. This means an MRI finding does not necessarily
 explain your pain.

 Kronisk tendinopati

 unngå

 Partielle senerupturer

 unngå
 

 Kortison kan svekke allerede skadet senevev ytterligere og Øke risikoen for komplett ruptur.

 

 
 
 Gjentatte injeksjoner

 Forsiktighet
 

 Mer enn 3-4 injeksjoner i samme område per Ør frarades. Gjentatte injeksjoner Øker risikoen for vevssskade betydelig.

 

 
 
 Når Øvelser ikke er prøvd

 Forsiktighet
 

 Kortison bør sjelden våre førstevalg. Strukturert rehabilitering bør forsøkes først i de fleste tilfeller.

 

 
 Absolutte kontraindikasjoner

 
 Aktiv infeksjon i eller når injeksjonsområdet

 Ukontrollert diabetes (kortison Øker blodsukker)

Forklar behandling av hekseskudd for Hekseskudd.

Behandling av hekseskudd

 Behandlingen av hekseskudd fokuserer på smertelindring, gjenoppretting av funksjon og forebygging av tilbakefall. Forskning støtter en aktiv tilnærming fremfor passiv hvile.

 Anbefalte tiltak
 Hold deg i bevegelse (viktigst)

 Sengeleie frardes. Forsiktig aktivitet og normale daglige gjøremål fremmer tilheling. Gå korte turer og gjør milde bevegeøvelser så snart smertene tillater det.

 Manuell behandling

 Kiropraktisk behandling inkludert leddmobilisering, bløtvevsmassasje og muskelutløsende teknikker kan gi smertelindring og bedre bevegelighet. Behandlingen tilpasses individuelt basert på funn og symptomer.

 Øvelsesveiledning

 Spesifikke øvelser for å gjenopprette bevegelse og styrke er viktig. Du vil få veiledning i øvelser tilpasset din fase av tilheling.

 Varme/kulde

 Varme kan lindre muskelspenning, mens is kan hjelpe ved akutt betennelse de første 48-72 timene. Bruk det som gir deg best lindring.

 Medikamenter

 Ved behov kan reseptfrie smertestillende som paracetamol eller ibuprofen brukes kortsiktig. Ved sterke smerter kan legen vurdere sterkere smertestillende eller muskelavslappende midler.

 "Tidlig aktiv behandling gir bedre resultater enn å vente og se. Forskning viser at pasienter som får behandling innen første uker har bedre langtidsutfall."

Prevention – stay injury-free on the course

 Most golf injuries are preventable. Here are the three most important measures based on research.

 10-minute warm-up protocol

 An effective warm-up before golf should include dynamic stretching and a gradual increase in swing speed. Here is a simple routine
 Before you swing: 10 minutes

 Minutes 1-3: Brisk walking or light jogging to raise body temperature

 Minutes 3-5: Dynamic stretching - trunk rotations, arm circles, hip flexors, hamstrings. Hold 2 seconds per position, 10 repetitions

 Minutes 5-7: Swing with two irons together (for resistance) at a slow tempo. 10-15 swings with gradual increase

 Minutes 7-10: Start with a wedge/short iron at the range. Build up to full speed over 10-15 balls

 Strength and mobility: 3 times per week

 A preventive training program for golfers should focus on three main areas
 Training program for golfers

 Focus Area 
 Exercises 
 Sets/Reps 

 Core musculature 
 Pallof press, dead bug, plank with rotation, side plank 
 3 x 10-12 

 Thoracic mobility 
 Open book, cat-cow, thread the needle, foam roller extension 
 2 x 10 

 Hip mobility 
 90/90 stretch, hip CARs, pigeon stretch, deep squat hold 
 2 x 10 

 Gluteal strength 
 Romanian deadlift, hip thrust, lateral band walk 
 3 x 10-12 

 Scapular stability 
 Rows, face pulls, external rotation with band 
 3 x 12-15 

 Technique improvement

 Even small adjustments in technique can have a major impact on loading
 Avoid reverse spine angle: Keep a slightly bent lead knee during the backswing and allow the upper body to rotate over the trail hip, not away from it.

 Hip-initiated downswing: Start the downswing with a lateral hip shift followed by rotation. This creates a natural sequence that offloads the lower back.

 Balanced finish: End the swing in a stable position with weight over the lead foot. If you lose your balance, the swing is too hard for your current mobility level.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 55-year-old male with acute, extremely painful, red and swollen knee. Fever 38.5C. Cannot weight-bear. No preceding trauma.

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY (emergency department)

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute monoarthritis — septic arthritis until proven otherwise.

Clinical reasoning:
- Acute monoarthritis with fever = septic arthritis FIRST in differential
- Redness + swelling + warmth + pain + loss of function = classic acute inflammation
- Septic arthritis is a SURGICAL EMERGENCY (joint washout)
- Gout can look similar, but delayed treatment of septic arthritis = joint destruction
- Rule: "Hot, swollen joint with fever = joint aspiration FIRST"
- Joint aspiration distinguishes septic arthritis from crystal arthritis (gout)

ACTION: Emergency department SAME DAY. Joint aspiration for culture and crystal analysis. Blood cultures. Do NOT give antibiotics before samples taken. NO manual treatment of the joint.

 Acute Phase (weeks 0-2)

 Relative Rest

 cushion between the three tendons (sartorius, gracilis, semitendinosus) and the bone.

Symptoms: The pain from pes anserine bursitis is below the joint line, while meniscus pain is

Treatment: Treatment is almost always conservative with good results

What is the prognosis for Headache on Top of the Head?

Prognosis

 

 Most people with headache on top of the head have a good prognosis. Tension headache and neck-related causes often respond well to treatment.

 Short-term

 Good probability of improvement with treatment - one study found that 72% of patients with cervicogenic headache maintained at least 50% reduction in headache frequency after 12 months.

 Relapses are Common

 Headache tends to return, especially with persistent risk factors like stress and static work. This does not mean treatment has failed - it means prevention and self-management are important.

 Long-term

 Evidence suggests that different treatments often give similar results over time. The most important factor for sustained improvement appears to be regular exercises and lifestyle changes.

Patient asks: "What is sensorimotor integration?"

Describe The Chiropractor's Role for ICR Syndrome.

The Chiropractor's Role

 

 As a chiropractor, my most important role with ICR syndrome is to recognize warning symptoms and refer appropriately. ICR syndrome can resemble jaw pain and other musculoskeletal conditions, but requires different management:

 
 History: Identify symptoms that may indicate vascular pathology

 Red flags: Identify warning symptoms for dissection or temporal arteritis

 Referral: Send to emergency department or GP for further investigation

 Caution: Avoid neck manipulation when vascular pathology is suspected

 

 
 Important warning symptoms to watch for

 
 New onset one-sided neck/headache

 Horner's syndrome (drooping eyelid, small pupil)

 Pulsatile tinnitus

 Age over 50 with new headaches + jaw claudication

 Symptoms after neck trauma

 Transient neurological symptoms

 
 

 
 Contraindications for neck manipulation

 
 Suspected carotid or vertebral artery dissection

 Recent neurological symptoms

 Known atherosclerosis or aneurysm in neck vessels

 Ongoing anticoagulation treatment for vascular causes

 
 When in doubt - don't treat. Refer for investigation first.

Describe treatment options for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Treatment

 

 This is the key message: 75-90% of patients with cervical disc herniation and
 radiculopathy improve significantly without surgery. Danish national guidelines from 2017 recommend
 manual treatment combined with exercises as first choice, before medication is considered.

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A systematic review from 2021 found that manual treatment showed effect in all included studies,
 regardless of technique. The consensus is that the combination of manual therapy and exercises gives
 better results than each treatment alone.

 
 Treatment may include:

 
 Joint mobilization of cervical vertebrae and upper back

 Soft tissue treatment of tight muscles in neck and shoulder

 Neural mobilization (gentle movement of the nerve along its path)

 Exercise instruction - strength and stability, especially deep neck flexors

 Ergonomic guidance and workstation adjustment

 
 

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Stay active - avoid prolonged bed rest

 Exercises - do the exercises your practitioner gives you regularly

 Ergonomics - adjust screen, chair and work position

 Pillow - a supportive pillow that keeps the neck in neutral position

 Heat or cold - experiment with what gives the best relief

 

 Treatment course

 
 Acute phase (0-4 weeks): 2-3 treatments per week, focus on pain relief and mobility
 

 Rehabilitation phase (4-12 weeks): 1-2 treatments per week, increasing focus on
 self-exercises and function

 Maintenance: As needed. Guidelines reco...

What causes Pain Behind the Shoulder?

Common causes of posterior shoulder pain

 

 
 
 Infraspinatus tendinopathy

 Most common
 

 Infraspinatus is one of four rotator cuff muscles and the second most common to
 injure. The muscle lies on the back of the shoulder blade and is responsible for external
 rotation of the shoulder.

 
 Pain behind the shoulder, may radiate toward the elbow

 Worsens with external rotation against resistance

 Often related to swimming, throwing and overhead activity

 
 

 
 
 Internal impingement

 

 Occurs when the rotator cuff (especially infraspinatus and supraspinatus) gets pinched against the
 posterior labrum when the arm is in "throwing position" (abducted and maximally externally rotated).
 

 
 Pain behind the shoulder in the "late cocking" phase of throwing

 Common in baseball pitchers, handball players, volleyball - similar mechanics as in thrower's shoulder

 Can cause secondary damage to labrum and rotator cuff

 
 

 
 
 GIRD (Glenohumeral Internal Rotation Deficit)

 

 Deficit in internal rotation of the shoulder, common in throwing athletes. 72% of handball players
 have GIRD. Often caused by tightening of the posterior shoulder capsule.

 
 Reduced internal rotation compared to the opposite side

 Increased external rotation (as compensation)

 Increased risk of shoulder problems and injuries

 
 

 
 Other causes

 
 Teres minor tendinopathy: Similar picture to infraspinatus

 Posterior labrum injury: Often together with internal impingement, can develop

Describe symptoms in adults for Scheuermann's Disease.

Symptoms in Adults

 When the skeleton is fully developed, treatment goals change. The structural kyphosis cannot
 be reversed, but symptoms, function, and quality of life can be significantly improved.

 The symptom picture in adults is often more complex than in adolescents
 Chronic or recurrent pain between the shoulder
 blades 

 Morning stiffness that improves with activity

 Reduced mobility in thoracic spine

 Muscle fatigue and tension (can resemble fibromyalgia-related chest pain )

 With curves over 75 degrees: reduced breathing capacity and endurance (see breathing, stress and back )

 Aesthetic concerns for some

 Uplifting News

 A Swedish study of older men (69-81 years) with Scheuermann's disease found no increased
 incidence of neck or back pain compared to peers without the condition (Jonsson et al.,
 Acta Orthop, 2023). As many as 25% of adults with Scheuermann's report actually no back
 pain.

Patient asks: "Is MdDS a psychiatric condition?"

No. MdDS is a neurological condition that probably involves maladaptation in the brain's balance centers. Anxiety and depression can follow prolonged illness, but are not the cause of MdDS. Another functional dizziness disorder is vestibular hypofunction , which is due to actual damage to the balance organ.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Brystryggsmerter: årsaker, Symptomer og Behandling?

Stillesitting og "kontorrygg"

 Folk sitter mer enn noen gang. Studier viser at langvarig sitting (over 7 timer daglig) er assosiert med redusert mobilitet i brystryggen og økt risiko for smerter. En fremoverlent holdning foran PC eller mobil øker belastningen på muskulaturen i øvre rygg betraktelig.

 Blant kontorarbeidere rapporterer opptil 34% plager i øvre rygg i løpet av et år (Briggs et al., 2009).

Stress og pustemønster å den "usynlige" Årsaken

 Gå til full artikkel om pust, stress og ryggsmerter ? 

 Stress setter seg ofte fysisk i kroppen. Ved høyt stress endres pustemønsteret til å bli mer overfladisk å søkalt brystpust. Dette overbelaster hjelpemuskulaturen i nakke og brystrygg.

 Resultatet blir en ond sirkel: Spenninger fører til smerte, smerte fører til endret pustemønster, endret pust gir mer spenninger.

 Kjenner du deg igjen? Det er ikke "bare i hodet". Sammenhengen mellom stress og fysisk smerte er godt dokumentert å og det finnes konkrete ting du kan gjøre.

Leddysfunksjon (fasettledd og costovertebralledd)

 Gå til full artikkel om ribbeinslasning ? 

 Stive eller irriterte ledd i ryggsøylen eller der ribbeina fester seg kan gi skarpe, lokaliserte smerter. Mange kaller dette "ribbeinsløsning" å en tilstand som responderer godt på behandling.

Holdningsrelaterte plager

 Gå til full artikkel om holdningsrelaterte plager ? 

 Økt kyfose (fremoverlent holdning) belaster brystryggen unødvendig. Skjermarbeid, mobilbruk og stillesitting er vanlige utløsende faktorer.

Kostokondritt og Tietzes syndrom

 Gå til full artikkel om kostokondritt ? 

 Betennelse i bruskovergangen mellom ribbein og brystbein. Gir smerter på fremsiden av brystet som kan ligne hjertesykdom, men har en muskel-skjelett-Årsak.

Scheuermanns sykdom

 Gå til full artikkel om Scheuermanns sykdom ? 

 En utviklingsforstyrrelse som gir økt kyfose hos ungdom. Rammer 1–8% av befolkningen (AAPMR, 2024). Diagnostiseres vanligvis i alderen 12–17 år.

Patient asks: "What is the difference between non-specific and specific back pain?"

Specific back pain has an identifiable cause: disc herniation with nerve involvement, fracture, infection or serious disease. These account for only 10-15% of cases, of which disc herniation makes up 3-5% (Maher et al., Lancet 2017). Non-specific back pain (85-90%) has no single identifiable structural cause.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Teeth Grinding (Bruxism).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between sleep bruxism and awake bruxism?

 Sleep bruxism occurs unconsciously at night with rhythmic grinding movements (50-80 kg force), while awake bruxism is daytime clenching often linked to stress and concentration. They require different treatment.

 

 
 Can SSRI medications cause teeth grinding?

 Yes. Studies show 20-24% of SSRI users develop bruxism, vs 2-10% in the general population. Symptoms often start 3-4 weeks after starting. Talk to your doctor if you suspect a connection.

 

 
 Is there a connection between sleep apnea and teeth grinding?

 Yes, research shows that up to 50% of sleep apnea patients also have bruxism. Grinding may be a protective mechanism to open airways. Therefore, sleep apnea should be ruled out before treating with night guard.

 

 
 Does a night guard help with bruxism?

 Night guard protects teeth but doesn't reduce the grinding itself. With sleep apnea, night guard can actually worsen the condition by pushing the jaw backward. The guard should be combined with cause-based treatment.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor treat bruxism?

 Yes, chiropractors can treat the muscle and joint component of bruxism through jaw joint mobilization, neck treatment and trigger therapy in jaw muscles. I often collaborate with dentists.

Explain Overtraining and Overuse to a patient.

Exercise is supposed to make you stronger, faster, and more resilient. But what happens when it backfires? When you train hard day after day, yet performance drops, motivation disappears, and your body protests with pain, illness, and exhaustion? You may have crossed the line from productive training to overuse – or in the worst case, overtraining syndrome.

 Overtraining is not just an elite athlete problem. It affects recreational exercisers, CrossFit enthusiasts, marathon runners, and anyone who pushes themselves without sufficient recovery. In this article, we explain the spectrum from normal fatigue to full-blown overtraining syndrome, how to recognize the warning signs, and what you can concretely do to prevent and treat the condition.

Beskriv Anatomi for Kne- og leggsmerter – Komplett guide.

Anatomi

 

 Kneet er kroppens største ledd og forbinder lærbenet med skinnebenet. Stabiliteten avhenger av et samspill mellom fire hovedligamenter (fremre og bakre korsbénd, innvendig og utvendig sidebénd), to halvmåneformede bruskskiver (meniskene), og kneskålen som Øker muskelkraften ved strekking.

 Leggen bestar av skinnebenet (den vektbørende knokkelen) og leggbenet (tynnere, hovedsakelig for muskelfester). Leggmuskulaturen å med gastrocnemius og soleus som de viktigste å er avgjørende for gange, løping og hopping.

Provide a structured clinical overview of T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms.

Causes and Risk Factors: Since T4 syndrome is poorly defined in research, we don't have reliable data on causation. The leading
 theory involves the sympathetic nervous system
Symptoms: The most characteristic feature of T4 syndrome is the bilateral, "glove-like"
 distribution of symptoms. Unlike carpal tunnel syndrome or nerve root compression from the
 neck, the symptoms do not follow a specific dermatomal pattern.

Diagnosis: T4 syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion . There are no validated diagnostic criteria or
 specific tests that can confirm the diagnosis (Karas & Pannone, 2017; NHS Scotland, 2019). The
 diagnosis is made by
Treatment: Treatment of T4 syndrome focuses on restoring mobility in the upper thoracic spine. It's important to be
 clear that all treatment evidence comes from case reports (evidence level 5) - there are no randomized
 controlled trials on patients with T4 syndrome (Karas & Pannone, 2017).

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor: These symptoms may indicate
 serious conditions such as myelopathy, MS, or other neurological diseases requiring rapid investigation.

Prognosis: There are no published data on long-term prognosis or recurrence rates for T4 syndrome. What is known is
 based on case reports and clinical experience

Explain treatment for Hip Labral Tear.

Treatment

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 Research shows that 50-80% of patients with labral tears recover sufficiently with
 conservative treatment.

 Conservative treatment includes
 Activity modification - avoid provocative movements temporarily

 Strength training - focus on hip musculature and core

 Mobility training - within pain-free ranges

 Manual therapy - soft tissue and joint mobilization

 Gradual return to activity

 Chiropractic treatment

 As a chiropractor, I can contribute with
 Thorough examination - assess extent and causes

 Manual therapy - mobilization of hip and pelvis

 Soft tissue treatment - release tight musculature

 Exercise program - individually tailored rehabilitation

 Referral when needed - for MRI or orthopedic assessment

 Surgery (arthroscopy)

 Surgery is considered only when
 Conservative treatment over 3-6 months does not provide sufficient improvement

 Mechanical symptoms (catching) dominate

 Significant FAI that needs correction

 Rehabilitation after surgery

 Even after successful surgery, rehabilitation is crucial. Full return to sport typically takes 6-12
 months. Without proper rehabilitation, the risk of poor outcome is higher.

Describe the four main types for Chronic Daily Headache.

The Four Main Types

 ICHD-3 (International Classification of Headache Disorders) defines four main types of chronic daily headache with attack duration over 4 hours
 1. Chronic Migraine 

 Most common 

 Headache 15+ days/month, with at least 8 days having migraine features (one-sided, pulsating, nausea, light/sound sensitivity). Develops gradually from episodic migraine - about 2.5-3% progress annually.

 Often aura or prodromal symptoms

 Worsens with physical activity

 Can respond to migraine preventive medications

 2. Chronic Tension Headache 

 Bilateral, pressing/tightening pain that does not worsen with activity. Mild to moderate intensity. No nausea, at most one of light or sound sensitivity.

 Can feel like a tight band around the head

 Often associated with muscle tension in neck/shoulders and trigger points 

 Stress is an important trigger

 3. Medication Overuse Headache (MOH)

 78-80% of CDH 

 The elephant in the room. Regular use of painkillers can paradoxically lead to more headache. Found in up to 78-80% of all chronic daily headache patients.

 Triptans: 10+ days/month

 Common painkillers: 15+ days/month

 Combination preparations/opioids: 10+ days/month

 4. New Daily Persistent Headache (NDPH)

 Rare 

 Sudden onset with daily, unrelenting headache from day one. The patient often remembers exactly when it started. Can resemble tension headache or migraine, but is distinguished by the acute onset.

 Important to Remember

 Most with chronic daily headache do not have just one type - many have overlapping diagnoses. For example, a person may have chronic migraine complicated by medication overuse.

Describe What is Calcific Tendinitis? for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Calcific Tendinitis?

 

 Calcific tendinitis is a condition where calcium crystals deposit in the rotator cuff tendons, most
 commonly in the supraspinatus tendon. The deposits vary in size from small dots to lumps several
 centimeters large.

 The condition goes through several phases and is self-limiting - meaning the calcium
 will eventually be reabsorbed by the body. The problem is that this can take anywhere from a few months
 to several years, and in the meantime, the pain can be significant.

 How common is calcific tendinitis?

 Calcific tendinitis is one of the most common causes of shoulder pain:

 
 
 2.7-7.8%
 prevalence in population
 

 
 2x
 women affected more often
 

 
 40-60 years
 typical age group
 

 
 10-20%
 have it in both shoulders
 

 

 
 Who gets calcific tendinitis?

 
 Women are affected twice as often as men

 Most common between 40 and 60 years

 Often the non-dominant shoulder (left for right-handed people)

 Increased prevalence with metabolic disorders (diabetes, thyroid)

 Sedentary work may be a risk factor

What is the prognosis for Flat Back (Hypokyphosis)?

Prognosis

 

 Untreated hypokyphosis

 A 30-year follow-up study found that patients with hypokyphosis had 10 times increased risk of needing
 neck surgery compared to those with normal kyphosis (MDPI, 2022).

 With treatment

 
 Available case reports show that structural improvement is possible - average 10-14 degrees increase in
 kyphosis in motivated patients. Pain often reduces significantly.

 

 Realistic expectations

 Treatment evidence is very limited. Not everyone will have the same benefit, and some structural changes
 cannot be reversed. The goal is often to improve function and reduce symptoms.

Describe causes and risk factors for Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck.

Causes and Risk Factors

 From most common to rarest
 Myofascial Dysfunction and Trigger Points (most common)

 58.5% had myofascial pain syndrome, and 59.7% of these had dizziness. Tight muscles - especially in the suboccipital muscles, upper trapezius and sternocleidomastoid - can disturb proprioceptive signaling.

 Joint Stiffness in the Upper Neck

 The upper cervical joints (C0-C1-C2) contain a very high density of proprioceptive sensors. When these joints become stiff, inaccurate signals are sent to the brain.

 Whiplash and Neck Injuries

 Dizziness is reported in 20-58% of patients with whiplash-associated injury.

 Prolonged Poor Head Posture

 "Tech neck" - constantly leaning head forward in front of screens.

 Risk Factors

 Gender: Women have 1.64 times higher risk

 Occupation: Office work with lots of screen time

 Stress: Increases muscle tension in neck and shoulders

 Previous neck injury: Whiplash, falls, sports injuries - including concussion

 Glidningen måles i prosent av virvelens bredde:

 
 
 
 Grad
 Glidning
 Betydning
 
 
 
 
 Grad I
 0-25%
 Mild - ofte asymptomatisk
 
 
 Grad II
 25-50%
 Moderat - konservativ behandling

 Svært alvorlig

 >100%

 Viktig å vite

What causes Thoracic Back Pain – Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

3 Common Causes of Thoracic Back Pain

 Most thoracic back pain is caused by mechanical issues that can be effectively treated by a chiropractor:

 
 Rib Joint Dysfunction (Costovertebral Dysfunction)

 The most common cause of thoracic back pain. Occurs when the joints between the ribs and vertebrae become stiff or "locked."

 
 Sharp pain with breathing and movement

 Point tenderness at the rib attachment

 Often triggered by twisting or lifting

 Responds very well to chiropractic treatment

 
 

 
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation in the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone. Causes pain at the front of the chest but often related to thoracic dysfunction.

 
 Tender to touch at the breastbone

 Can mimic heart pain

 Worse with coughing and deep breathing

 Often self-limiting, but treatment helps

 
 

 
 Thoracic Facet Joint Dysfunction

 Stiffness or irritation in the small joints between the vertebrae in the thoracic spine.

 
 Stiff and aching pain between the shoulder blades

 Worse with extension (bending backward)

 Often related to poor posture

 Common in office workers

 
 

 
 Myofascial Trigger Points

 Painful knots in the muscles, especially in the rhomboids, trapezius, and erector spinae.

 
 Often refer pain to other areas

 Can cause headaches and neck pain

 Often related to stress and overload

 Treated effectively with soft tissue treatment

 
 

 
 Poor Posture and Ergonomics

 Prolonged poor loading from office work, mobile phone use, or on...

Describe symptoms and signs of Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Symptoms of Acute Back Pain

 

 Symptoms of acute back pain are typically localized to the lower back and can vary in intensity:

 Characteristic symptoms:

 
 Acute pain: Sudden onset, often described as "stabbing" or "paralyzing"

 Stiffness: Significantly reduced mobility in the back

 Muscle tension: Often palpable tension in the back muscles

 Pain intensification: Movement, coughing, sneezing, and straining worsen the pain
 

 Relief at rest: Pain often decreases in stationary positions

 

 
 Important distinction: Uncomplicated vs. Complicated

 In uncomplicated acute back pain, the pain is limited to the lower back without radiating symptoms to
 the legs. If you experience radiating pain, numbness, or weakness in the legs, this may indicate nerve
 involvement (sciatica) and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.

Describe Important to know in the context of Pain in Arm, Elbow and Hand.

Golfer's elbow (medial epicondylitis)

 7-10x rarer than tennis elbow
 

 Go to full article on golfer's elbow →

 Golfer's elbow is like tennis elbow, except the pain is on the inside of the elbow. The condition is
 7-10 times rarer than tennis elbow and affects 0.4-1% of the population. Over 90% of cases are
 due to work-related strain - tradespeople, carpenters, plumbers and butchers are far more
 often affected than golfers.

 
 Important to know

 The ulnar nerve runs just behind the tender area. 20-60% of patients with golfer's
 elbow have concurrent nerve irritation causing tingling in the ring and little finger. This can
 significantly prolong treatment time.

Describe treatment options for ICR Syndrome.

Treatment

 

 Treatment depends entirely on the underlying cause:

 
 
 Carotid Dissection

 

 
 Antithrombotic treatment: Blood thinners (anticoagulation or antiplatelet)

 Hospitalization: For monitoring and acute treatment

 Endovascular treatment: Stenting if needed

 Duration: Antithrombotic treatment for 3-6 months

 
 

 
 
 TIPIC / Idiopathic Carotidynia

 

 
 NSAIDs: Ibuprofen or naproxen

 Steroids: If NSAIDs are insufficient

 Prognosis: Often self-limiting over weeks

 
 

 
 
 Temporal Arteritis

 

 
 High-dose steroids: Started immediately on suspicion

 Biopsy: Of temporal artery to confirm diagnosis

 Long-term treatment: Tapering over months to years

Forklar Knesmerte fra hoften for en pasient.

Du har vondt i kneet, men problemet sitter egentlig i hoften. Dette hores kanskje rart ut, men det er faktisk ganske vanlig. Kroppen fungerer som en kjede der leddene påvirker hverandre - det vi kaller den kinetiske kjeden. Knesmerter kan derfor ha mange ulike årsaker.

 Når hoftemuskulaturen er svak - særlig gluteus medius (setemuskel på siden) og utoverrotatorene - mister du kontroll over larbenet under belastning. Resultatet er at kneet kollapser innover, noe fagfolk kaller "dynamisk knevalgus". Dette skaper unødvendig belastning på strukturer inne i og rundt kneet.

 Forskning fra 2004 viste at 33% av pasienter med knesmerte også hadde hofteplager , og over halvparten av dem med hoftesmerte rapporterte også knesymptomer. Blant pasienter med patellofemoralt smertesyndrom - den vanligste formen for fremre knesmerte - finner man typisk 21-36% svakere hoftemuskulatur sammenlignet med friske.

 Faktorer som bedrer prognosen:

 
 
 Trening
 Den viktigste modifiserbare faktoren
 

 
 Tidlig
 diagnose og helhetlig behandling

 Behandling av depresjon og søvnproblemer

Kjennetegn på karpaltunnelsyndrom

 
 Fingre påvirket: Tommel, pekefinger, langfinger, og halve ringfinger

 Verre om natten: Mange vakner av nummenhet og må riste på handen

 Lindres ved risting: å riste på handen gir ofte kortvarig lindring

 Ingen nakkesmerte: Symptomene er lokalisert til hand og underarm

 Risikofaktorer: Graviditet, diabetes, hypothyreose, repetitivt arbeid

 Svakhet: Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan tommelmuskulaturen bli svakere

 
 

 Ulnarisnerveaffeksjon (Cubitaltunnelsyndrom)

 Ulnarisnerven kan bli klemt ved albuen (cubitaltunnelen) eller ved handleddet (Guyons kanal).

 
 Kjennetegn på ulnarispåvirkning

 
 Fingre påvirket: Lillefinger og halve ringfinger (ulnare halvdel)

 Albueposisjon: Ofte verre ved bøyning av albuen eller ved å hvile på albuen

 Innsiden av handen: Kan gi svakhet i de små handmusklene

 "Klofingre": Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan fingrene få kloliknende stilling

 
 

 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 Nervene og blodarene til armen kan bli klemt i området mellom nakkebasis og armhulen.

 
 Kjennetegn på TOS

 
 Nummenhet og prikking i hele handen eller flere fingre

 Ofte forverret av å holde armene over hodet

 Kan gi kuldefølelse og fargeforandringer i handen

 Ofte forbundet med dårlig holdning eller ekstra nakkeribben

Explain prognosis and living with as for Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Prognosis and Living with AS

 The prognosis for ankylosing spondylitis has improved dramatically with modern treatment. Most people
 can live active, productive lives with good disease control.

 The positive
 Biologic medications provide good disease control for most

 Early treatment can prevent structural damage

 Many maintain full work capacity

 Regular exercise significantly improves quality of life

 The disease "burns out" in some after years

 The realistic
 Chronic disease requiring lifelong follow-up

 Flare-ups may occur

 Fatigue can be challenging to manage

 Some experience gradual reduced mobility despite treatment

 Increased risk of osteoporosis and fractures

 Lifestyle adaptations

 Stop smoking: Smoking significantly worsens the disease and reduces treatment
 effectiveness

 Regular exercise: Daily exercises for mobility

 Good sleep hygiene: Firm mattress, correct pillow height

 Ergonomics: Adaptations at work and home

 Regular follow-up: With rheumatologist and possibly other specialists

Document Gonstead cervical chair adjustment for C5 subluxation.

Gonstead cervical analysis C5:

Nervoscope: Temperature differential C5 right.
Static palpation: Edema and tenderness C5 articular pillar right.
Motion palpation: C5 body left (C5-BL) — restricted rotation right.
X-ray: C5-BL listing confirmed on APOM view.

Adjustment:
- C5-BL: Cervical chair adjustment.
  Patient seated, head tilted slightly left.
  Contact: Right lamina/articular pillar C5.
  LOD: L→R, P→A.
  Stabilizing hand: Left mastoid.
  Specific HVLA rotatory thrust.
- Post-check: Temperature equalized, improved right rotation, patient reports reduced stiffness immediately.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Cervikal Foraminal Stenose.

Hva er cervikal foraminal stenose?: Cervikal foraminal stenose betyr at nerveåpningene på siden av nakkevirvlene har blitt trangere. Disse åpningene kalles "foramen" (flertall: foramina) og er der spinalnervene forlater ryggsøylen for å forsyne armer og hender med følelse og bevegelse.

Årsaker til foraminal stenose: Den vanligste årsaken. Over tid kan virvlene utvikle beinpåleiring (osteofytter) som vokser inn i foramen og gjør apningen trangere.

Symptomer: En klassisk test for foraminal stenose: Hodet bøyes bakover og roteres mot smertefull side, deretter trykkes lett ned. Positiv test reproduserer utstråling til armen. Dette "lukker" foramen og provoserer symptomene.

Behandling: De fleste med cervikal foraminal stenose responderer godt på konservativ behandling. Studier viser at 75-90% oppnår god symptomkontroll uten kirurgi.

Røde flagg - Når må du søke lege?: Disse symptomene kan indikere cervikal myelopati (påvirkning av ryggmargen) eller andre alvorlige tilstander som krever rask vurdering.

Differential diagnoses for Ankylosing Spondylitis?

HLA-B27

 90-95% positive 

 A gene found in most people with ankylosing spondylitis. However: 8% of the general population also
 has this gene without developing the disease. A positive test is supportive but not diagnostic alone.

Inflammatory markers

 CRP and ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) may be elevated but are normal in up to 40% of patients.
 Normal CRP does not rule out ankylosing spondylitis.

Pelvic X-ray

 Shows sacroiliitis (changes in the SI joints). Required for classic AS diagnosis according to New
 York criteria. May be normal early in the disease course.

MRI

 Important for early diagnosis 

 Can show active inflammation (bone marrow edema) in SI joints and spine before X-ray changes occur.
 Crucial for diagnosing non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Differential diagnoses for Dizzy When Standing Up?

1. Orthostatic Hypotension (Blood Pressure Drop When Rising)

 This is the most common cause overall, accounting for around 42% of all dizziness cases. When you stand up, 500-1000 ml of blood collects in your legs due to gravity. Normally, the body compensates by increasing heart rate and constricting blood vessels. In orthostatic hypotension, these mechanisms fail, and the brain temporarily receives too little blood.

 Who is most affected? Elderly over 65, people taking blood pressure medication, diabetics (24% prevalence), and Parkinson's patients (30-40% prevalence).

 Typical symptoms: Lightheadedness and unsteadiness occurring seconds to minutes after standing up. Many experience "graying out" or tunnel vision. Symptoms disappear when sitting down again. Important: Symptoms never occur when lying flat.

2. BPPV (Crystal Disease)

 BPPV is the most common vestibular cause of position-related dizziness. Around 2.4% of the population experiences this during their lifetime, and the condition accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness consultations. Women are affected twice as often as men.

 BPPV occurs when small calcium crystals in the inner ear become dislodged and end up in the semicircular canals. This sends false rotation signals to the brain.

 Typical symptoms: Intense sensation of the room spinning. Episodes typically last 10-60 seconds and are triggered by head movements - including when turning over in bed. Nausea is common.

3. Medication Side Effects

 Over 250 medications can cause orthostatic hypotension. The main culprits include
 Alpha blockers carry highest risk

 Tricyclic antidepressants give six times increased risk

 Diuretics

 All types of blood pressure medication

What is the prognosis for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over?

Prognosis - How Does It Progress?

 

 With proper treatment, most experience significant improvement. Patients on preventive treatment see reduction in both frequency, intensity, and duration of attacks.

 Realistic Expectations

 
 Relapses are common: Even with good treatment, many will experience periods with more attacks

 Treatment takes time: It may take 2-3 months before preventive medications have full effect

 Individual variation: What works for one person does not necessarily work for another

 

 The positive news is that many find that attacks become less intense and less frequent over the years, especially with good treatment and trigger management. In some cases, prolonged vestibular migraine can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), which requires a different treatment approach.

Explain prognosis for Frozen Shoulder: Everything You Need to Know.

Prognosis

 The positive
 Over 90% recover without surgery (Vastamäki et al., 2012)

 The condition is self-limiting - it resolves

 Most regain full or near-full mobility

 Treatment can shorten the course and relieve symptoms (Rangan et al., 2020)

 The realistic
 It takes time - typically 1-3 years

 Some have mild residual stiffness (usually without problems)

 Diabetics may have longer course and poorer response

 5-34% develop it in the other shoulder later

 Patience is key

 Frozen shoulder is frustrating because it takes time. But the important thing is that the condition almost always resolves. Proper treatment and exercises can relieve symptoms along the way and potentially shorten the course.

Describe symptoms for Pelvic Girdle Pain in Pregnancy.

Symptoms

 Where is the pain located?

 SI joint (back) - pain at the junction between lower back and buttock, often
 one-sided (pain on the outside may also be gluteal
 tendinopathy )

 Symphysis (front) - pain in the groin area, middle front (for deep groin pain,
 consider iliopsoas tendinopathy )

 Both - many have pain both front and back

 Radiation - can radiate to buttock, thigh and groin (read about piriformis syndrome for persistent buttock pain, or hamstring tendinopathy for pain higher on the back)

 Typical symptoms

 Pain when walking - especially long distances

 Pain when turning over in bed 

 Pain when standing on one leg - putting on pants, going up stairs

 Clicking or crunching in the pelvic joints

 Feeling of instability in the pelvis

 Difficulty spreading the legs 

 Pain worsens with
 Going up stairs

 Turning over in bed

 Standing on one leg (getting dressed)

 Prolonged standing or sitting

 Lifting

 Walking on uneven surfaces

 When should you contact a doctor?

 Sudden, severe pain

 Bleeding or discharge

 Fever together with pain

 Numbness or weakness in the legs (numbness on the front of the thigh may be meralgia paresthetica )

 Problems with bladder or bowel

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Foot and Ankle Problems.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Do I need a referral?

 No. Chiropractors have primary contact status in Norway. You can book an appointment directly without a
 referral from a doctor.

 

 
 Can you refer me onwards?

 Yes. I can refer to X-ray, MRI, CT and ultrasound covered by National Insurance. I can also refer to
 physiotherapy and specialists (orthopaedic surgeon, rheumatologist, neurologist).

 

 
 Can I get a sick note?

 Yes, chiropractors with documented competence can issue sick notes for up to 12 weeks.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 It varies by condition: Ankle sprain grade I-II: 1-6 weeks. Plantar fasciopathy: 6-12 weeks active
 treatment (80-90% better within 12 months). Metatarsalgia: 6-8 weeks. Achilles tendinopathy: 6-12
 months. Morton's neuroma: 3-6 months with conservative treatment.

 

 
 Can I train while in treatment?

 Often yes - The goal is "optimal loading": enough load to stimulate healing, but not so much that you
 worsen the injury. Complete rest is rarely the solution. I give specific advice tailored to your situation.

 

 
 Do insoles help?

 Can provide relief for some, but evidence is moderate. Important: prefabricated insoles work just as
 well as expensive custom-made ones for plantar fasciopathy. Stretching and strength training have better documentation.

Describe What about headache and bite? for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

What about headache and bite?

 

 The connection between malocclusion and headache is also poorly documented. Van der Meer and colleagues concluded in Cephalalgia (2019) that primary headaches like tension headache and migraine "are not caused by musculoskeletal dysfunction" - even though they may be associated with such symptoms.

 The International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3) recognizes "headache attributed to temporomandibular dysfunction" as secondary headache. But this relates to TMD itself - not to bite deviation directly.

Describe the most common causes of dizziness for You Don't Have to Live With Dizziness Anymore.

The Most Common Causes of Dizziness

 BPPV - Vertigo

 BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) is the most common cause of rotational dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. The condition occurs when small calcium particles dislodge in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

 Typical characteristics: Brief, intense dizziness episodes (seconds to one minute) triggered by head movements - such as turning in bed, bending down, or looking up.

 Treatment response: Studies show 80-90% improvement with repositioning maneuvers like Epley. Many experience improvement after one treatment, while others need 2-3 treatments. Success rate after repeated treatments is over 90-95%.

 Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related)

 Studies show that up to 40% of patients with neck pain also experience dizziness. The upper cervical vertebrae (C1-C3) contain a high concentration of position sense receptors that send information to the brain about head position. When these signals are disturbed, the result can be unsteadiness and dizziness.

 Typical characteristics: Persistent unsteadiness that worsens with neck movements, often combined with neck pain and headache.

 Treatment response: A systematic review from 2011 concluded that there is moderate evidence for manual treatment of cervicogenic dizziness. Treatment is often combined with specific exercises.

 Vestibular Neuritis

 An inflammation of the balance nerve, often after a viral infection. Causes sudden, intense dizziness that lasts for days to weeks.

 Treatment response: Vestibular rehabilitation shows significant effect. A Cochrane review found statistically significant improvement compared to no treatment.

 Other Causes

 Vestibular migraine, Meniere's disease, medication side effects, and orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure drop when standing) are among other common causes. Sometimes multiple conditions overlap.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Røde flagg ved Nakkesmerter.

Cervical arteriedisseksjon (CAD): Cervical arteriedisseksjon oppstår når det dannes en rift i den indre veggen av en av blodårene som forsyner hjernen å enten halspulsaren (arteria carotis interna) eller nakkeåren (arteria vertebralis). Blod kan trenge inn i karveggen og danne en blodansamling som innsnevrer eller blokkerer blodstrømmen til hjernen.

Symptomer ved CAD: Det vanligste symptomet er hodepine og/eller nakkesmerte (65-95% av pasientene). Men CAD-relatert smerte har kjennetegn som skiller den fra vanlige muskelplager
Cervical myelopati: Cervical myelopati oppstår når ryggmargen i nakken blir klemt eller trykket på. Dette skiller seg fra vanlig nakkesmerte eller nerverotsirritasjon ved at selve ryggmargen å ikke bare nervene som går ut fra den å påvirkes. Tilstanden regnes som den vanligste årsaken til ryggmargsdysfunksjon hos voksne (Lancet Neurology, 2019).

Symptomer ved myelopati: Cervical myelopati har en karakteristisk symptomtriade (AAFP, 2020)
Prognose uten behandling: Naturlig forløp uten behandling er bekymringsfullt
Kiropraktorens rolle ved røde flagg: Ved mistanke om arteriedisseksjon eller myelopati er kiropraktorens viktigste oppgave tidlig gjenkjennelse og rask henvisning. Jeg behandler ikke pasienter der det foreligger mistanke om disse tilstandene.

Vurder røde flagg: 42 år mann. Akutt ensidig nakkesmerte etterfulgt av kontralateral armsvakhet og beinsvakhet. Også Horners syndrom ipsilateralt til smerten.

AKUTT: Mistanke om vertebral arterie-disseksjon med hjernestammeinfarkt. Ipsilateral nakkesmerte med Horners og kontralateral hemiparese (Wallenberg variant). Ring 113 umiddelbart. Akutt sykehus for MR/MRA og nevrologisk vurdering. Vaskulær nødsituasjon.

Patient asks: "How do I know if my rib is broken or just dislocated?"

The most important clue is the trauma history. With a fracture, you remember exactly what happened - a fall, a blow, an accident. With dislocation, the history is often more vague. The intensity is also different - fractures typically cause more intense pain that makes it difficult to take deep breaths.

Explain Mal de Debarquement Syndrome to a patient.

Mal de debarquement - French for "sickness of disembarkation" - is a condition most people have experienced. After a boat trip, it can feel like the ground is still swaying for a few hours. For most people, this sensation disappears within one to two days. Dizziness can have many causes, and MdDS is one of the rarer ones.

 For some, the experience becomes long-lasting. When the rocking sensation persists for more than 48 hours, and often months to years, we talk about Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS). This is a rare neurological condition affecting approximately 1.3% of patients at neuro-otological clinics.

 The condition is characterized by a persistent, non-spinning dizziness - often described as "rocking", "swaying motion" or "bobbing". Many use descriptions like "it feels like being on a boat all the time" or "the ground is moving under me".

Explain how can chiropractic help? for Jaw Joint Problems.

How Can Chiropractic Help?

 Most people with TMD improve without surgery. A systematic review from 2024 concluded that conservative
 treatment should be first choice – surgery is relevant for less than 5% (Dentistry Journal 2024). 75-90% respond to conservative treatment , about 40% experience spontaneous improvement , and less than 5% need surgery .

 Treatment approach

 Examination: Assessment of jaw, neck, posture and mobility

 Muscle treatment: Release of tight chewing muscles and trigger points

 Joint mobilisation: Gentle techniques for better jaw joint mobility

 Neck treatment: Upper neck vertebrae (C0-C3) are often involved

 Exercises: Individually tailored home programme

 Advice: Ergonomics, stress management, sleep hygiene

 Typical course: 6-10 treatments over 2-3 months.

 Honestly speaking

 Relapses are common if triggering factors aren't managed. Stress, poor ergonomics and teeth grinding
 must be addressed – otherwise the problems often return.

Describe Osteophytes in the context of Spinal Stenosis - Narrowing in the Spine.

Osteophytes

 Bone spurs that grow into the spinal canal or nerve exits.

 

 Risk Factors with Documented Association

 
 Age over 60: 3-5 times higher prevalence

 Obesity: BMI over 30 gives more than double the risk

 Diabetes: Found in 29% of stenosis patients vs 10% in the general population

 Spondylolisthesis: Vertebral slippage can
 contribute to stenosis

 
 

 
 
 
 3
 Symptoms

 

 The classic symptom of lumbar spinal stenosis is called neurogenic claudication - a
 term describing the typical pattern many experience:

 
 Pain, heaviness or numbness in one or both legs

 Symptoms come gradually when walking or standing upright

 Relief when sitting down, bending forward or leaning on a shopping cart

 Often easier to cycle than walk (because you sit slightly forward-leaning)

 

 These symptoms can resemble sciatica, but with stenosis the typical pattern
 is that symptoms worsen with walking and improve with rest in a forward-bent position.

 
 The Shopping Cart Sign

 This is so characteristic that it's used diagnostically worldwide. Many patients report they can walk
 much further when leaning on a shopping cart. This is because leaning forward expands the spinal canal
 and gives more room for the nerves.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Osteoporose og kompresjonsfrakturer i ryggen.

Medisinsk behandling

 

 Behandling av den underliggende osteoporosen er legens ansvar. Her er en kort oversikt over hva som finnes:

 Medikamentell behandling

 Bisfosfonater (alendronat, zoledronat) er førstelinjebehandling. Metaanalyser viser 38 % reduksjon i total frakturrisiko, 45 % reduksjon i vertebrale frakturer og 34 % reduksjon i hoftefrakturer (PMC, 2017).

 Teriparatid (PTH-analog) viser størst effekt på vertebrale frakturer - opptil 77 % risikoreduksjon - og brukes ved høyrisiko-pasienter (Bone, 2020).

 Denosumab er et alternativ når bisfosfonater ikke tolereres, men effekten forsvinner raskt ved seponering med risiko for rebound-frakturer.

 Vitamin D og kalsium er standardtilskudd ved osteoporose: 800-2000 IE vitamin D daglig og 1000-1200 mg kalsium. Dette er spesielt viktig i Norge der vitamin D-mangel er utbredt.

 Akuttfasen

 De første dagene etter et akutt kompresjonsbrudd fokuserer behandlingen på smertelindring (paracetamol, eventuelt kortvarig opioid), kort sengeleie (1-3 dager, men ikke langvarig!) og eventuelt ryggortose for stabilisering.

Describe Digestion and the Diaphragm - An Overlooked Connection for Breathing, Stress and Back.

Digestion and the Diaphragm - An Overlooked Connection

 

 Reflux and Breathing Function

 Here the evidence is surprisingly strong. The diaphragm contributes approximately 85% of the
 pressure function at the junction between the esophagus and stomach (Mittal, 1993). When the
 diaphragm functions poorly, the risk of acid reflux increases.

 A study on patients with diaphragmatic paresis (Kaufman et al., 2022) found that 26.3% had GERD
 (gastroesophageal reflux disease). With bilateral paresis, this rose to 36.8%.

 Breathing Training for Reflux - Does It Work?

 Yes, actually better than many think. Several randomized controlled trials show convincing results:

 
 
 Eherer et al. (2012)

 30 minutes of daily belly breathing for 4 weeks reduced acid exposure from 9.1% to 4.7%. At 9-month
 follow-up, participants had reduced PPI use to one-third.

 

 
 Sun et al. (2016)

 After 6 months of diaphragm biofeedback, 82% had stopped acid-suppressing
 medications (vs. 6% in the control group).

 

 
 Halland et al. (2021)

 Diaphragmatic breathing increased pressure in the lower esophageal sphincter from 23.1 to 42.2 mmHg.
