Describe symptoms in adolescents for Scheuermann's Disease.

Symptoms in Adolescents

 Many young people with Scheuermann's disease have few or no symptoms and discover the
 condition by chance. When symptoms occur, they typically include
 Visible rounding or "hump" in upper back (see also kyphosis )

 Mild to moderate back pain, especially with activity

 Stiffness in thoracic spine, especially after rest

 Back fatigue after school or activity

 With severe curves: breathing difficulties (rare in adolescents)

 Diagnosis

 The diagnosis is made by clinical examination combined with X-rays. Sorensen criteria
 require
 Diagnostic Criteria (Sorensen)

 Thoracic kyphosis over 40 degrees (measured with Cobb angle)

 At least 3 consecutive vertebrae with wedging of 5 degrees or more

 Often irregular endplates and Schmorl's nodes on X-ray

 Important Differentiation

 In postural (posture-related) kyphosis, the patient can actively straighten the back by
 hyperextension. In Scheuermann's, the curve is rigid and cannot be actively corrected -
 this is a key finding in clinical examination.

 Severity

 Grade 
 Cobb Angle 
 Measures 

 Mild 
 40-50 degrees 
 Observation, exercise 

 Moderate 
 50-70 degrees 
 Brace + exercise 

 Severe 
 Over 70-75 degrees 
 Surgical assessment

Describe diagnosis for Athletic Pubalgia.

Diagnosis

 Clinical examination

 The diagnosis is primarily clinical. Five findings that support athletic pubalgia
 Deep groin/lower abdominal pain that worsens with sports activity and improves with rest

 Palpation tenderness over the pubic ramus at the rectus abdominis attachment

 Pain with resisted hip adduction

 Pain with resisted sit-up

 No palpable inguinal hernia

 Resisted adduction sit-up test (RASUT)

 78% sensitivity and 88% negative predictive value. A valuable test to support the
 diagnosis in a clinical setting.

 Imaging

 MRI is the standard imaging modality when confirmation is needed. MRI has 68%
 sensitivity and 100% specificity for rectus abdominis injury, and 86% sensitivity and 89% specificity for
 adductor tendon injury.

 Important to remember

 MRI findings must be interpreted cautiously. Studies have shown that asymptomatic ice hockey players
 often have MRI changes resembling athletic pubalgia.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Runner's Knee (PFPS) - How to Return to Full Distance.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the hip paradox?

 The hip paradox describes how weak hip muscles can cause knee pain. When the hip
 abductors are weak, the knee collapses inward with each step, overloading the patellofemoral joint.
 The solution is to strengthen the hip.

 

 
 Can I continue running?

 Often yes, but with adjustments. Reduce distance and intensity to a level where
 pain stays below 3/10. Many benefit from increasing cadence by 5-10%.

 

 
 How long is the rehabilitation time?

 Most see improvement within 6-12 weeks with proper treatment. 40% have some
 symptoms after 1 year, but this doesn't mean they can't run - just that complete symptom resolution
 can take time.

 

 
 Do orthotics help?

 Research is mixed. Some benefit, especially with overpronation, but they're not
 first-line treatment. Hip strengthening and running form adjustments have better documented
 effectiveness.

 

 
 Should I change shoes?

 Shoes should be comfortable, but there's no "best" shoe for runner's knee. If
 shoes are worn out (over 600-800 km), it's wise to replace them. Avoid drastic changes in
 cushioning/drop.

 

 
 What about knee braces/patella tape?

 Can provide short-term symptom relief for some, but doesn't address the
 underlying causes. Use as a supplement if helpful, but not as a replacement for exercise.

 

 See all knee pain FAQs ?

Describe Myofascial trigger points in the context of Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Myofascial trigger points

 Active trigger points in the upper trapezius occur in 30-40% of patients with chronic neck pain. Causes radiation that can mimic radiculopathy.

 

 Risk factors

 
 Age over 50

 Heavy physical work with lifting over 25 kg

 Work with vibrating equipment

 Prolonged driving

 Smoking (affects blood supply to discs)

 Sedentary work with poor ergonomics

 Previous back pain (41% have had lumbar radiculopathy)

 
 

 
 
 3
 Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each?

 

 The neck has seven cervical vertebrae, and the nerves exiting between them are named after the vertebra
 above. Note: Only 62.6% of patients have standard dermatome patterns, and 67.3% show typical myotome
 patterns (Neurospine 2022). About one-third have atypical symptoms.

 
 C7 radiculopathy (most common - 60-70% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C6-C7

 Sensory: Tingling, numbness in the middle
 finger (finger 3). May also be felt on the back of the forearm.

 Muscle weakness: Triceps (elbow extension), wrist flexors and finger extensors.
 

 Reflex change: Reduced triceps reflex.

Describe treatment options for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

Treatment

 

 
 Chiropractic treatment may include:

 
 Trigger point therapy: Targeted pressure to release active trigger points

 Manual mobilization: Restore normal joint mobility in neck

 Soft tissue treatment: Massage and myofascial techniques

 Dry needling: Needle treatment of trigger points

 Exercise instruction: Home exercises for strength and relaxation

 
 

 Exercises you can do yourself

 
 Neck stretches

 Gently tilt your head toward one shoulder. Hold for 30 seconds. Repeat to the opposite side. Do 3
 times each side, several times daily.

 

 
 Shoulder rolls

 Roll your shoulders slowly backward in large circles. Do 10 repetitions. This loosens tension in the
 upper trapezius.

 

 
 Chin tucks

 Pull your chin straight back as if making a "double chin." Hold for 5 seconds. Repeat 10 times.
 Corrects forward head posture.

 

 
 Breathing exercises

 Deep diaphragmatic breathing activates the parasympathetic nervous system and reduces muscle tension.
 Breathe in for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds, breathe out for 6 seconds. Repeat for 5 minutes.

 

 Stress management

 For lasting improvement, underlying stress often needs to be addressed:

 
 Regular physical activity

 Adequate sleep (7-9 hours)

 Relaxation techniques (meditation, yoga)

 Social support and work-life balance

 If needed: Professional help for stress management

Differential diagnoses for When Dizziness Doesn't Fit: Is It BPPV or Something Else??

1. BPPV/Crystal Disease (17-39% of clinical cases)

 The most common vestibular diagnosis, but far from the only one. Lifetime prevalence in the population is 2.4%, and cumulative risk is approximately 10% by age 80.

 Brief dizziness (seconds) with head movements

 Triggered by lying down, turning over in bed, looking up

 Positive Dix-Hallpike test

 Note: Up to 41% of BPPV patients do NOT have classic spinning sensation. Many describe a "nautical" feeling, unsteadiness, or lightheadedness instead.

2. Vestibular Migraine (6-29% of dizziness patients)

 The second most common cause of recurrent dizziness, and severely underdiagnosed. Only 10% of those meeting diagnostic criteria are told that migraine causes their symptoms. The condition affects 0.98-2.7% of the general population.

 Dizziness episodes lasting minutes to days

 Headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual disturbances in at least half of attacks

 Previous or current migraine history

 Migraine patients have three times higher risk of developing BPPV

 Important: When repositioning maneuvers don't work after three attempts, vestibular migraine should be strongly suspected.

3. PPPD - Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness (15-20%)

 PPPD is the most common chronic dizziness condition in people aged 30-50. It often develops as a complication of other vestibular conditions - including untreated BPPV.

 Dizziness/unsteadiness most days for at least 3 months

 Worsened by standing upright, movement, and busy visual environments

 Often triggered by a previous vestibular event

 Anxiety worsens the condition

 Approximately 70% of PPPD cases start with a structural vestibular disorder like BPPV.

4. Vestibular Neuritis (3.5-15.5 per 100,000/year)

 Acute inflammation of the balance nerve, often following viral infection.

Hvorfor oppstar triggerpunkter?

 

 Triggerpunkter utvikles når muskelfibre blir overbelastet eller skadet. De vanligste Årsakene i arm og underarm:

 
 Repetitive bevegelser: Musbruk, tastatur, handverkerarbeid

 Statisk belastning: Holde armen i samme stilling over tid

 Akutt overbelastning: Lofting, uvant aktivitet

 Darlig ergonomi: Feil arbeidsstilling ved datamaskin

 Stress og spenning: Forhøyet muskelspenning over tid

 Kulde: Trekk eller kald eksponering

 

 
 Hva skjer i muskelen?

 Triggerpunkter oppstar når motoriske endeplater (der nerven måter muskelen) blir overaktive. Dette fører til vedvarende sammentrekning av muskelfibrene, redusert blodtilførsel, og opphopning av avfallsstoffer. Resultatet er en Øm, stram knute.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Hekseskudd.

Hva er hekseskudd?: Hekseskudd er en folkelig betegnelse på akutte ryggsmerter lokalisert til korsryggen (lumbalområdet). Medisinsk kalles det ofte akutt lumbago. Smerten oppstår typisk plutselig, ofte i forbindelse med en bevegelse som løfting, vridning eller boying, men kan også komme uten tydelig utløsende årsak.

Årsaker til hekseskudd: I de fleste tilfeller (ca. 90%) er hekseskudd det man kaller uspesifikke korsryggsmerter. Det betyr at smertene ikke kan tilskrives en spesifikk patologisk årsak som kan påvises på billeddiagnostikk.

Symptomer på hekseskudd: Symptomene ved hekseskudd er typisk lokalisert til korsryggen og kan variere i intensitet
Diagnostikk: Diagnosen hekseskudd stilles primært gjennom sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. Bildediagnostikk er som regel ikke nødvendig ved ukompliserte tilfeller.

Behandling av hekseskudd: Behandlingen av hekseskudd fokuserer på smertelindring, gjenoppretting av funksjon og forebygging av tilbakefall. Forskning støtter en aktiv tilnærming fremfor passiv hvile.

Røde flagg - Når du må søke lege: Selv om hekseskudd vanligvis er en godartet tilstand, finnes det varselsignaler som krever rask medisinsk vurdering. Les mer om røde flagg her .

Prognose og forløpet: Den gode nyheten er at hekseskudd har svært god prognose for de aller fleste
Forebygging: Selv om akutte episoder ikke alltid kan forhindres, er det mye du kan gjøre for å redusere risikoen

Describe Meniere's Disease - A Chronic Condition in the context of Dizziness - Causes, Symptoms and Effective Treatment.

Meniere's Disease - A Chronic Condition

 Meniere's disease is a chronic disorder of the inner ear caused by increased fluid pressure (endolymphatic hydrops). The condition causes classic attacks with four main symptoms:

 
 Severe rotatory vertigo (20 minutes to several hours)

 Fluctuating hearing loss (low frequency)

 Tinnitus (ringing in the ears)

 Pressure sensation in the affected ear

Forklar prognose - hvordan går det? for Hodepine Etter Nakkesleng.

Prognose - Hvordan går det?

 De første 3 månedene er avgjørende

 Forskning viser at bedring hovedsakelig skjer i løpet av de første 3 månedene etter skaden. Etter dette flater bedringskurven dramatisk ut. En studie fant at 86% av de som fortsatt var symptomatiske ved 3 måneder, forble symptomatiske etter 2 år.

 Tre typiske forløp (Sterling et al., JOSPT 2016)

 ~50% 
 Mild bane: Full bedring 

 ~30% 
 Moderat bane: Vedvarende moderate plager 

 ~20% 
 Alvorlig bane: Kronisk funksjonsnedsettelse 

 Risikofaktorer for dårlig utfall

 Høy initial smerteintensitet, høy funksjonsnedsettelse fra starten, kuldefølsomhet, smertekatastrofisering og posttraumatiske stressymptomer øker risikoen for kronifisering. Lave forventninger til bedring er en sterk negativ prognostisk faktor.

 Tilbakefall er vanlig

 Selv blant de som blir bra, opplever mange tilbakefall. Langtidsstudier viser at bare omkring 35% er fullt restituert etter 5 år. Dette understreker viktigheten av å lære strategier for egenmestring.

Identify red flags for Overpronation: Myth or Medical Fact?.

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor

 

 
 Seek medical attention immediately for:

 
 Sudden, intense foot pain without apparent cause

 Swelling, redness, and warmth combined with fever

 Numbness or tingling that doesn't go away

 Foot sores that don't heal (especially with diabetes)

 Significant change in foot shape over a short time

 Pain that worsens significantly with activity and doesn't improve with rest

 Sudden development of flat foot in an adult (may indicate tendon damage)

 
 

 Even though overpronation is not a valid diagnosis, there are real foot problems that require medical evaluation. Persistent pain should always be examined by a professional.

Unilateral vestibulær hypofunksjon (ensidig)

 Ved ensidig hypofunksjon er balanseorganet skadet på kun en side. Dette er den vanligste formen og skyldes oftest vestibularisnevritt (virus på balansenerven).

 Hvordan fungerer det? Balanseorganene i høyre og venstre Øre fungerer normalt som et "push-pull"-system. Når du snur hodet til høyre, Økersignalet fra høyre Øre mens det minker fra venstre. Ved ensidig skade oppstar en ubalanse som hjernen tolker som konstant rotasjon. Den gode nyheten er at hjernen er bemerkelsesverdig flink til å kompensere for ensidig skade.

Årsaker og utløsende faktorer: POTS har ingen enkelt årsak, men utloses ofte av en "immunologisk stressor". De vanligste utløsende faktorene er
Symptomer: POTS gir et bredt spekter av symptomer som varierer fra person til person.

Diagnostikk: For å fa diagnosen POTS må du oppfylle
Behandling: Det finnes ingen kur for POTS, men de fleste får betydelig bedring med riktig behandling. Ikke-medikamentelle tiltak er førstelinjebehandling.

Prognose: Prognosen ved POTS varierer betydelig

Diagnosis

 The combination of headache and dizziness requires thorough assessment to distinguish between the various causes
 Vestibular Migraine - Diagnostic Criteria

 At least 5 episodes of vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Duration 5 minutes to 72 hours

 Current or previous migraine

 At least one migraine feature during 50% of episodes

 Cervicogenic Dizziness

 Diagnosis is made by ruling out other causes and demonstrating a connection between neck problems and dizziness
 Dizziness triggered by neck positions or movements

 Neck pain or stiffness present

 Other vestibular causes ruled out

 Positive response to neck treatment

 Special Examinations

 When vestibular causes are suspected, VNG examination (videonystagmography) and TRV chair can be useful for mapping balance function.

Vurder røde flagg: 48 år mann, kontorarbeider med vanlig nakkesmerte. Ved rutineanamnese oppgir han at han har tatt Marevan (warfarin) for ny atrieflimmer de siste 4 ukene. INR-nivå ukjent.

HASTEGRAD: MONITORÉR

Ingen akutte røde flagg, men VIKTIG medikamentell kontraindikasjon.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Warfarin = antikoagulasjon = økt blødningsrisiko
- Spinal manipulasjon hos antikoagulerte pasienter medfører risiko for epiduralt hematom
- INR ukjent = kan være i terapeutisk eller supratherapeutisk område
- Ny warfarin (4 uker) = INR kan være ustabilt

Dette er IKKE en akutt nødsituasjon, men endrer behandlingsplanen:

HANDLING:
1. INGEN spinal manipulasjon (høyhastighetsteknikker) før INR er kjent og stabil
2. Be pasient kontakte fastlege for INR-måling
3. Forsiktig mobilisering og myofascielle teknikker kan brukes
4. Dokumentér medikamentbruk og tilpasset behandlingsplan
5. Ved INR <3.0 og stabil: forsiktig mobilisering OK. Ved INR >3.0: kun myofascielt.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Stiff Neck.

What exactly is a stiff neck?: Stiff neck is an umbrella term for acute neck stiffness with pain and restricted range of motion. It can be caused by several different mechanisms that often occur together
Common Causes: From most to least common
Symptoms and Duration: The typical presentation is pain and stiffness in the neck, usually one-sided, with clearly restricted range of motion — especially rotation and side-bending. The pain may radiate upward toward the head or downward toward the shoulders.

Red Flags — When Should You See a Doctor?: The vast majority of stiff neck cases are harmless and self-limiting. However, certain symptoms require prompt medical evaluation.

Self-Help and Home Treatment: The first 48 hours are crucial. Here is a step-by-step approach based on clinical guidelines
Chiropractic Treatment: Treatment with a chiropractor can help achieve faster pain relief and restore normal movement. A Cochrane review concludes that spinal manipulation may be effective for neck pain (Gross et al. 2015).

Prevention: You cannot ensure it will never happen again — 50-75% experience recurrent episodes (clinical consensus). But you can significantly reduce the risk

Patient with headache, dizziness, neck pain, and tinnitus. Which codes?

Multi-system presentation coding:

Primary: L83 — Neck syndrome
Secondary:
- N95 (Tension headache) — headache component
- N17 (Vertigo/dizziness) — dizziness component
- H03 (Tinnitus) — tinnitus

Rationale: Cervical origin can explain all four symptoms. L83 should be primary.

Error: Coding four separate primary diagnoses without identifying common origin.

 Bevegelsen: Spre tårne så langt fra hverandre som mulig

 Fokus: Prøv spesielt å spre stortåen bort fra de andre

 Hold: 5-10 sekunder

 Gjentagelser: 10-15 repetisjoner

 Sett: 2-3 sett per fot

 
 

 
 Tips: Bruk tøseparatØrer

 Hvis du sliter med å spre tårne, kan tøseparatØrer (toe spacers) hjelpe. Bruk dem passivt mens du sitter eller sover for å gradvis gjenvinne tøbevegelighet. Start med 15-30 minutter og Øk gradvis.

Beskriv Hva sier forskningen? for Minimalistsko og barfottrening: Hva sier forskningen?.

Hva sier forskningen?

 

 Liverpool-studien (Curtis 2021)

 Den mest omfattende studien på minimalistsko og fotstyrke ble publisert i Scientific Reports (Nature) i 2021. Forskerne fulgte deltakere som gikk over til minimalistsko i hverdagen:

 
 
 57,4%
 styrkekning
 

 
 d=0,84
 Cohen's d (står effekt)
 

 
 5mm
 høyere fotbue
 

 

 
 Hovedfunn fra Liverpool-studien

 Etter 6 maneder med daglig bruk av minimalistsko viste deltakerne 57,4% Økning i fotstyrke - uten noen spesifikke treningsØvelser. Cohen's d på 0,84 indikerer en står og klinisk betydningsfull effekt. I tillegg okte fotbuens hoyde med gjennomsnittlig 5mm.

 

 Barfotpopulasjoner

 Studier av befolkninger som tradisjonelt går barfot eller i minimale sandaler gir verdifull innsikt:

 
 
 
 Studie
 Funn
 
 
 
 
 India-studien (Sachithanandam & Joseph)
 Halvparten så mange tilfeller av plattfot blant de som gikk barfot
 
 
 D'Aout et al. (2009)
 Indiske barfotgåre hadde jevnere trykfordeling og sterkere fotter
 
 
 Hollander et al. (2017)
 Barn som gikk barfot hadde bedre balanse og motØriske ferdigheter
 
 
 Tarahumara-folket
 Loper ultramaraton i tynne sandaler med svært fa skader
 
 
 

 Lopeskader

 En studie av Taddei et al. (2020) i American Journal of Sports Medicine underskte løpere med styrket fotmuskulatur:

 
 2,4 ganger færre skader

 Løpere som trente fotmusklene (som også styrkes av minimalistsko) hadde under halvparten så mange løperelaterte skader som kontrollgruppen.

 

 
 Viktig advarsel

 Stu...

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain when should you not exercise? for Shoulder Exercises.

When should you NOT exercise?

 Exercise is almost always beneficial for the shoulder, but there are situations where you should wait and get an assessment first.

 Stop exercising and see a healthcare professional if
 Recent injury: Fall on the shoulder or direct trauma within the last 48 hours

 Unstable shoulder: Repeated dislocations (shoulder comes out of joint)

 Unexplained pain with radiation: Pain, numbness or tingling radiating down the arm

 Post-surgical: After shoulder surgery without clearance from your surgeon

 Sudden loss of strength: Unable to lift the arm after an acute event

 Night pain: Persistent pain that wakes you from sleep

 What can a chiropractor do?

 Thorough examination: Clinical tests to identify the cause of your pain

 Individualized exercise program: Tailored to your specific diagnosis and functional level

 Manual therapy: Joint mobilization, soft tissue techniques and trigger point treatment

 Guidance: Correct technique, progression, and when to seek medical attention
You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain treatment for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Treatment

 Progressive strength training is key

 Research shows that heavy, progressive strength training is the well-documented treatment
 for PHT.

 Treatment principles
 Start with isometric exercises (holding position)

 Gradually build up to heavier loads

 Focus on strength, NOT stretching

 Be patient - this takes time

 Phase 1: Pain control (weeks 1-2)

 Reduce compression - avoid prolonged sitting on hard chairs

 Use a cushion - relieve the sit bone

 Isometric exercises - hamstring activation without movement

 Avoid stretching! 

 Phase 2: Strength building (weeks 2-8)

 Bridging progressions - from two-leg to single-leg

 Romanian deadlift - controlled hip flexion

 Nordic hamstring curl - eccentric strength

 Hip thrust - gluteal activation

 Phase 3: Functional training (weeks 8-12+)

 High loads - 80-90% of maximum strength

 Explosive training - jumps, sprints

 Running-specific training - gradual return

 Manual treatment

 Soft tissue treatment - can relieve muscle tension

 Pelvic and hip mobilization 

 Nerve mobilization - for nerve irritation

 When is injection/surgery considered?

 Cortisone injection - can provide short-term relief, not first choice

 PRP injection - uncertain effect

 Surgery - rare, only for long-term failure of conservative treatment

Røde flagg og gule flagg

 Gule flagg - risiko for vedvarende plager

 Bevegelsesunngåelse: Tro på at smerte alltid betyr skade

 Katastrofetanker: "Det kommer aldri til å gå over"

 Gule flagg er ikke skyld

You are a quick clinical text assistant. Generate concise clinical summaries for chiropractic documentation.
Provide a structured clinical overview of Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

What is disc herniation and cervical radiculopathy?: Cervical radiculopathy means a nerve root in the neck is irritated or compressed. This
 causes symptoms radiating to the shoulder, arm or hand - often called "nerve root involvement,"
 "brachialgia" or colloquially: "pinched nerve in the neck."

Causes and risk factors: Interestingly, only 14.8% had physical exertion or trauma just before symptom onset in the Rochester
 study. Most cases develop gradually without a specific triggering event.

Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each?: The neck has seven cervical vertebrae, and the nerves exiting between them are named after the vertebra
 above. Note: Only 62.6% of patients have standard dermatome patterns, and 67.3% show typical myotome
 patterns (Neurospine 2022). About one-third have atypical symptoms.

Carpal tunnel or neck? How to tell the difference: Numbness in the hand can come from the neck (cervical radiculopathy) or from the wrist (carpal tunnel
 syndrome). Symptoms can be similar, but there are important differences. One study showed that 62.2% of
 patients with cervical radiculopathy also have carpal tunnel syndrome - so-called "double crush
 syndrome."

Diagnosis: A thorough clinical examination is often more important than imaging. The chiropractor assesses neck
 mobility, muscle strength, sensation and reflexes.

Treatment: This is the key message: 75-90% of patients with cervical disc herniation and
 radiculopathy improve significantly without surgery. Danish national guidelines from 2017 recommend
 manual treatment combined with exercises as first choice, before medication is considered.

Red flags - when you should see a doctor: These signs may indicate cervical myelopathy (spinal cord involvement) or
 other serious conditions requiring prompt evaluation.

Prognosis: The prognosis for cervical radiculopathy is generally good. Most improve significantly with
 conservative treatment, and only a minority need surgery.

Hva forårsaker Cervikal Foraminal Stenose - Trang Nervekanal i Nakken?

Årsaker til foraminal stenose

 

 
 Spondylose (slitasje)

 Den vanligste Årsaken. Over tid kan virvlene utvikle beinpåleiring (osteofytter) som vokser inn i foramen og gjør apningen trangere.

 

 
 Skiveforandringer

 Diskusutbuling eller prolaps kan presse på nerveroten. En "hard" herniering med beinpåleiring er vanligere ved stenose enn "myk" diskusprolaps.

 

 
 Fasettleddsartrose

 Slitasje i fasettleddene fører til fortykkelse av leddkapselen og beinpåleiring som reduserer plassen i foramen.

 

 
 Ligamentum flavum-fortykkelse

 Det gule leddbandet kan bli tykkere med alderen og bidra til innsnevring.

 

 Risikofaktorer

 
 Alder: Risikoen Øker betydelig etter 50 Ør

 Tidligere nakkeskade: Whiplash eller andre traumer

 Arbeid med nakkebelastning: Langvarig arbeid med hodet fremover eller i rotasjon

 Genetikk: Noen har naturlig mindre foramen

 Røyking: Akselererer degenerative forandringer i ryggsøylen

Forklar prognose for Krystallsyke.

Prognose

 BPPV er en godartet tilstand med svært god prognose. Reposisjonsmanvrer gir umiddelbar bedring hos de fleste.

 Restsvimmelhet etter behandling

 31-61% av pasientene rapporterer vedvarende lett svimmelhet eller ustohet etter vellykket behandling, selv om nystagmus og posisjonsell vertigo er borte. Denne restsvimmelheten varer vanligvis i median 10 dager og forsvinner som regel innen 3 måneder. Hos noen kan dette utvikle seg til PPPD (vedvarende postural-perseptuell svimmelhet) .

 Tilbakefall er vanlig

 Ca. 15-23% opplever tilbakefall innen første ør

 5-Ørs tilbakefallsrate er rundt 40%

 Opp til 50% kan oppleve ny episode innen 5 år

 Forebygging av tilbakefall

 D-vitamintilskudd hos pasienter med påvist mangel kan redusere risikoen for nye episoder. En meta-analyse viste signifikant reduksjon i tilbakefallsrate (relativ risiko 0,37).

Forklar behandling - heavy slow resistance for Hopperkne.

3 Behandling - Heavy Slow Resistance

 Treningsbasert behandling er hjørnesteinen for seneplager. Heavy Slow Resistance (HSR) har vist seg minst like effektivt som eksentrisk trening.

 Heavy Slow Resistance (HSR) protokoll

 Tunge styrkeøvelser med langsom hastighet
 Tempo: 3 sekunder opp, 3 sekunder ned

 Belastning: 70-85% av maksimal styrke

 Repetisjoner: 6-15 RM

 Frekvens: 3-4 ganger per uke

 Varighet: 12 uker minimum

 Typiske øvelser

 Kneboying: Squat med langsom kontroll

 Benstrekk: I maskin med langsom fase

 Decline squat: På skrå brett (25 grader) for økt senebelastning

 Utfall: Med kontrollert tempo

 Smerte under trening?

 Moderat smerte (under 5/10) er akseptabelt under trening. Smerten bør ikke øke over dager/uker. Hvis smerten øker, reduser belastningen midlertidig.

Hva forårsaker Triggerpunkter i Nakken - Muskelknuter og Referert Smerte?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Triggerpunkter utvikles når muskelfibre blir overbelastet eller skadet. De vanligste Årsakene, rangert etter hvor ofte vi ser dem:

 
 Statisk belastning og dårlig ergonomi (vanligst)

 Langvarig skrivebordsarbeid, skjermbruk med fremskutt hode, og ensidig arbeid er de klart vanligste Årsakene. Kontorarbeidere og manuelt arbeidende har tilsvarende triggerpunktfordeling, med gjennomsnittlig 6 aktive og 10-11 latente triggerpunkter (Fernandez-De-Las-Penas 2012).

 

 
 Muskulær overbelastning

 Repetitive bevegelser, tunge løft, eller plutselig Økt treningsbelastning.

 

 
 Stress og anspenthet

 Psykisk stress fører ofte til kronisk muskelspenning, særlig i nakke og skuldre.

 

 
 Andre faktorer

 
 Søvnproblemer og utmattelse: Dårlig søvn reduserer musklenes evne til restitusjon

 Vitamin D-mangel: Omtrent en tredjedel av MPS-pasienter har lave D-vitaminnivåer (StatPearls 2025)

 Traumer: Whiplash og andre skader. Blant whiplash-pasienter har 55-65% triggerpunkter i levator scapulae

 
 

 
 Hvem rammes?

 MPS forekommer oftest i aldersgruppen 27-50 Ør. Kvinner rammes oftere enn menn - 65% mot 37% blant middelaldrende voksne (Steen, Muscle & Nerve 2025).

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Describe diagnosis for SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Diagnosis

 SI joint pain is primarily diagnosed clinically. There is no single test that is 100% accurate, so we use
 a combination of several tests.

 Clinical Provocation Tests

 Distraction test - pressure outward on the hip bones

 Compression test - pressure inward on the hip bones

 FABER/Patrick's test - stress on the SI joint via the hip

 Thigh thrust - pressure through the thigh

 Gaenslen's test - one leg over the edge of the bed

 The 3 of 5 rule

 If 3 or more of these 5 tests are positive, there is over 90% probability that the pain originates from
 the SI joint.

 Imaging

 X-ray and MRI rarely show anything with functional SI joint problems. Imaging is most
 useful to rule out other conditions such as
 Arthritis in the SI joint

 Inflammatory disease (Ankylosing spondylitis)

 Fractures

 Infection

Forklar prognose - hva kan du forvente? for Spondylolistese: Glidning av virvler.

Prognose - hva kan du forvente?

 Prognosen for spondylolistese er generelt god, særlig for lavgradige glidninger.

 Det positive
 De fleste med grad I-II klarer seg godt med konservativ behandling

 Mange er helt symptomfrie selv med påvist glidning

 Glidningen stabiliserer seg vanligvis hos voksne

 Regelmessig trening kan forebygge forverring

 Det realistiske
 Tilstanden krever ofte livslang oppmerksomhet på trening og ergonomi

 Noen aktiviteter må kanskje modifiseres

 Perioder med oppbluss kan forekomme

 Regelmessig oppfølging kan være nyttig

 Hos barn og ungdom

 Unge idrettsutøvere med spondylolysis eller lavgradig spondylolistese har god prognose. De fleste kan returnere til idretten etter en periode med hvile og rehabilitering. Regelmessig oppfølging i vekstperioder er viktig for å fange opp eventuell progresjon.

Patient asks: "When should I consider surgery?"

Surgery is considered for acute trauma with sudden weakness in active individuals, full-thickness tears in younger patients who need a strong shoulder, and when there is no improvement after 3-6 months of structured rehabilitation. For degenerative tears in older adults, surgery is rarely the first choice.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Kne- og leggsmerter – Komplett guide.

Symptomer og Årsaker

 

 Vanlige symptommønstre

 
 Fremre knesmerte: Smerte rundt kneskålen, verre ved trapper, knebøy eller langvarig sitting

 Innvendig knesmerte: Langs innsiden av kneet å typisk ved meniskproblemer eller slitasje

 Utvendig knesmerte: På utsiden å ofte IT-bénd syndrom hos løpere

 Leggsmerte: Langs skinnebenet (beinhinnebetennelse) eller i leggmuskulaturen

 Tilleggssymptomer: Hevelse, stivhet, instabilitet, løsning, knasende lyder

 

 
 Overbelastning (vanligste Årsak)

 Overbelastningsskader oppstar når vevet utsettes for mer repetitiv belastning enn det tåler. Typiske eksempler: løperkne, hopperkne, IT-bénd syndrom og beinhinnebetennelse. Rask Økning i treningsmengde er en gjennomgående risikofaktor.

 

 
 Slitasje (degenerative forandringer)

 Med alderen får mange naturlige aldersforandringer i kne og menisker. De fleste degenerative meniskfunn på MR gir ingen symptomer. Kneartrose utvikler seg gradvis over Ør og gir Økende smerter, stivhet og redusert bevegelighet.

 

 
 Akutte skader

 Korsbéndskader, akutte meniskskader og muskelstrekk oppstar typisk ved plutselige bevegelser, fall eller direkte treff. Disse krever ofte en annen tilnærming enn overbelastningsskader.

 

 
 Biomekaniske faktorer

 Kneet fungerer ikke isolert. Problemer i hofte eller ankel påvirker belastningen på kneet. Svak hoftemuskulatur, overpronasjon i foten og dårlig knekontroll er vanlige bidragende faktorer som kan adresseres med målrettet trening.

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mistanke om spinal tuberkulose (Potts sykdom).

Forklar handkletrikset og behandling for Kubitaltunnelsyndrom: Alt du trenger å vite.

Handkletrikset og behandling

 De fleste med kubitaltunnelsyndrom blir bra uten operasjon. NØkkelen er å holde albuen strakt , spesielt om natten.

 Handkletrikset - enkel og effektiv

 Rull et handkle sammen til en pålse

 Legg det på innsiden av albuen (i albuebyen)

 Fest løst med tape, bandasje eller stretchbind

 Bruk hver natt under søvn

 Resultat: Studier viser 82% bedring med denne enkle metoden kombinert med aktivitetsmodifikasjon (Svernlov et al., 2009).

 Behandlingsplan hos . Aktivitetsmodifikasjon Viktigst 

 Identifisere og modifisere aktiviteter som forverrer symptomene. Unngå langvarig albuebøy og å lene på albuen.

 2. Nattskinne / Handkletrikset

 Holder albuen i strakt posisjon under søvn. Ofte det eneste som trengs for milde til moderate symptomer.

 3. Nerveglide-Øvelser

 Forsiktige øvelser som mobiliserer ulnarnerven gjennom sin bane fra nakke til hand.

 4. Manuell behandling

 Bløtvevsbehandling av omliggende muskulatur, mobilisering av albue og nakke.

 Når vurderes kirurgi?

 Symptomer som vedvarer til tross for 3-6 måneders konservativ behandling

 Konstant nummenhet

 Synlig muskelsvinn

 Betydelig svakhet i handen

Describe symptoms and characteristics for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Symptoms and Characteristics

 Main Symptoms
 Non-rotational dizziness: It doesn't spin, but it rocks, sways or feels like being on a boat

 Brain fog: Concentration difficulties, mental fatigue - reported by about 81%

 Exhaustion: Extreme tiredness, worst in the afternoon - reported by about 85%

 Visual hypersensitivity: Worsening in busy environments (shopping centers, supermarkets)

 Movement intolerance: Symptoms worsen with both active and passive movements (car, bus)

 Mental Health and PPPD

 60% of PPPD patients have clinically significant anxiety and 45% have depression, but 25% have no psychiatric condition at all. This underscores that PPPD is a neurological condition - not "just anxiety." Similar mental health challenges are also seen in other chronic dizziness conditions like Meniere's disease and MdDS .

 Red Flags - Call 113 or go to emergency room for
 Acute dizziness with headache - especially "the worst headache ever"

 Double vision, visual disturbances or visual field loss

 Speech difficulties or swallowing problems

 Numbness, weakness or paralysis in face, arm or leg

 Sudden one-sided hearing loss

 Dizziness with chest pain or palpitations
Sportskadevurdering: Hamstringsstrekk hos sprinter under konkurranse.

Akutt Hamstringsstrekk - Sprintskade

Klassifisering:
- Grad 1: Mild strekk, ubehag, full kraft, minimal hevelse
- Grad 2: Partiell ruptur, smerte ved kontraksjon, redusert kraft, hevelse
- Grad 3: Komplett ruptur, umulig å kontrakjere, stor hevelse, evt palpabel defekt

Akutt undersøkelse:
- Inspeksjon: Hevelse, hematom, defekt
- Palpasjon: Lokalisasjon (proksimalt = lengre rehabilitering)
- Kraft: Isometrisk knefleksjon i ulike vinkler
- ROM: Passiv kneekstensjon i 90° hoftefleksjon
- Spesialtester: Puranen-Orava, sittende kneekstensjon

Rehabiliteringsprogram:

Fase 1 (Dag 1-5): Akutt
- PRICE, krykker ved behov
- Isometrisk knefleksjon smertefritt
- Forsiktig gange

Fase 2 (Dag 5-14): Subakutt
- Eksentrisk styrking (Nordic hamstrings, lett)
- Gange uten halting
- Sykling, svømming

Fase 3 (Uke 2-4): Styrke
- Progresjon eksentrisk styrke
- Stående knefleksjon med motstand
- Jogg (70% fart)

Fase 4 (Uke 4-8): Return to sport
- Sprint-progresjon: 70% -> 80% -> 90% -> 100%
- Retningsendringer, akselerasjon, deakselerasjon
- Sport-spesifikk trening

Return-to-sport kriterier:
- Smertefri ved full belastning
- Kraft >90% av kontralateral
- Fullført sprint-progresjon uten symptomer

Grad 1: 2-3 uker. Grad 2: 4-8 uker. Grad 3: 3-6 mnd (evt kirurgi).

Beskriv symptomer på bekhterevs sykdom for Bekhterevs sykdom.

Symptomer på Bekhterevs sykdom

 Symptomene ved Bekhterevs skiller seg vesentlig fra vanlige ryggsmerter. Det klassiske mønsteret kalles "inflammatorisk ryggsmerte."

 Hovedelementer ved inflammatorisk ryggsmerte

 De fem karakteristiske tegnene

 Debut får 40 Ørs alder (95% debuterer får 45)

 Snikende start - gradvis utvikling over uker/måneder

 Bedring ved aktivitet - motsatt av mekaniske ryggsmerter

 Ingen bedring ved hvile - kan faktisk forverres

 Nattlig smerte - vakner av smerter, særlig andre halvdel av natten

 Morgenstivhet

 Et av de mest karakteristiske symptomene er uttalt morgenstivhet som varer mer enn 30 minutter - ofte 1-2 timer eller mer. Stivheten lettes gradvis med bevegelse og aktivitet.

 Andre symptomer

 Perifere ledd

 Betennelse i andre ledd, særlig hofter, skuldre og knær. Asymmetrisk leddbetennelse i større ledd.

 Entesitt

 Betennelse der sener fester til bein. Vanlige steder inkluderer akillessenen, plantarfascien (hålen) og bekkenområdet.

 Uveitt (regnbuehinnebetennelse)

 25-40% opplever dette 

 Akutt betennelse i øyet med smerte, rødhet og lysfølsomhet. Krever rask behandling hos øyelege.

 Tretthet

 Uttalt fatigue er vanlig og kan være like invalidiserende som smerten.

 Sammenligning: Inflammatorisk vs. mekanisk ryggsmerte

Describe Hallux Rigidus vs. Hallux Valgus for Hallux Rigidus (Stiff Big Toe).

Hallux Rigidus vs. Hallux Valgus

 

 It's important to distinguish between these two common big toe conditions:

 
 Hallux Rigidus (stiff big toe)

 
 Osteoarthritis in the base joint

 Main symptom is stiffness and pain with movement

 Bone spur (osteophyte) typically on top of the joint

 Big toe usually remains straight

 
 

 
 Hallux Valgus (bunion)

 
 Malalignment in the joint

 Main symptom is malalignment and pain over the bump

 Bump typically on the inside of the foot

 Big toe angles toward the other toes

 
 

 Both conditions can occur simultaneously, and treatment must be individually tailored.

Spontan resorpsjon - Prolapsen kan gå tilbake av seg selv

 

 Dette er kanskje den viktigste informasjonen mange pasienter ikke får: Kroppen har en bemerkelsesverdig evne til å resorbere prolapsert skivemateriale. Flere meta-analyser bekrefter dette.

 
 Resorpsjonsrater etter type

 En fersk meta-analyse av 31 studier med 2233 pasienter (Zou et al., Clinical Spine Surgery 2023) viser tydelige monstre:

 

 
 
 
 Prolapstype
 Resorpsjonsrate
 
 
 
 
 Sekvestrering (losrevet fragment)
 87-96%
 
 
 Ekstruksjon (brudd gjennom ytre ring)
 67%
 
 
 Protrusjon (buling med intakt ring)
 38%
 
 
 Bulging (generell utbuling)
 13%
 
 
 

 Hvorfor går de "verste" prolapsene best tilbake?

 Det jegrker motintuitivt, men forklaringen er biologisk: Når skivemateriale bryter helt gjennom og ligger fritt i ryggkanalen (sekvestrering), eksponeres det for kroppens immunsystem. Dette trigger en inflammatorisk respons med makrofager som "spiser opp" det fremmede vevet. Nydannelse av blodkar (neovaskularisering) understøtter denne prosessen.

 Ved mindre prolapser som fortsatt har kontakt med skiven, er denne immunresponsen svakere, og resorpsjonen går saktere.

 Tidslinje for resorpsjon

 
 Hovedperioden: Mesteparten av resorpsjonen skjer innen 3-6 måneder

 Tidlig resorpsjon: 24.7% viser tegn til resorpsjon innen 3 måneder

 Ved 12 måneder: 67-81% har dokumentert resorpsjon på MR

 Gjennomsnittlig tid: 8.7 +/- 3.2 måneder til fullstendig resorpsjon

 

 
 Symptomene bedres FOR MR-bildene endr...

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this is NOT giant cell arteritis (GCA):
- BILATERAL frontal tightness headache = typical tension headache
- GCA typically causes UNILATERAL temporal headache
- No temporal tenderness (temporal artery tenderness is classic for GCA)
- Normal chewing (jaw claudication is nearly pathognomonic for GCA)
- Normal vision (GCA threatens vision)
- ESR 15 and CRP 3 = NORMAL values (GCA typically causes ESR >50, often >80)

Clinical picture: Chronic tension-type headache.

Safe to treat with cervical/suboccipital treatment, ergonomics, stress management.

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain chiropractic perspective for Trigeminal Neuralgia.

Chiropractic Perspective

 Let us be straightforward: trigeminal neuralgia is a neurological condition that requires medical treatment. Chiropractic treatment cannot treat TN itself, and should not replace medications or surgery.

 Only case reports (individual patients) exist in the literature - no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) supporting chiropractic treatment of trigeminal neuralgia (ScienceDirect 2023).

 What the chiropractor can contribute

 1. Differential diagnosis

 Many patients present with facial pain without a diagnosis. We systematically examine for TMD , neck-related pain, dental problems - and identify when the pattern fits TN.

 2. Prompt referral

 When TN is suspected, we refer you to a neurologist or your GP for evaluation and medical treatment. Early diagnosis is important for good treatment outcomes.

 3. Treatment of concurrent complaints

 Many TN patients also have neck and jaw problems that exist in parallel. These are conditions we can help with - for example cervicogenic headache , tension headache , or TMD .

 4. Interdisciplinary collaboration

 Communication with the treating neurologist is important for the best possible outcome. We collaborate with the patient's broader healthcare team.

 Trigeminal neuralgia vs. TMD - an important distinction

 TMD (temporomandibular disorder) and trigeminal neuralgia affect overlapping areas of the face and jaw, and are often confused
 TN: Lightning-like, electric shock - seconds - triggered by light touch

 TMD: Dull, aching - minutes to hours - triggered by chewing and jaw use

 With TN, patients are pain-free between attacks. With TMD, there is often persistent discomfort.

Describe Dr. Richard Blake's Weaning Protocol for Orthotic Dependency: How to Wean Off.

Dr. Richard Blake's Weaning Protocol

 

 Dr. Richard Blake, a renowned podiatrist, has developed a gradual weaning protocol that gives your feet time to adapt:

 
 Phase 1: Preparation

 
 You must be pain-free for at least 2 weeks before starting the weaning process

 Start foot exercises now - this prepares the muscles

 Get shoes with some support (not minimalist shoes yet)

 Document your starting point - note how your feet feel

 
 

 
 Phase 2: Gradual Weaning

 
 
 
 Week
 Time without orthotics
 Activity level
 
 
 
 
 Week 1
 1 hour/day
 Only calm activities indoors
 
 
 Week 2-3
 3-4 hours/day
 Light daily activities
 
 
 Week 4-6
 Full day
 Normal daily activity
 
 
 Week 6-8
 Full day + light activity
 Gradual increase in physical activity
 
 
 
 

 
 Phase 3: Pain Monitoring

 
 Use a pain scale from 0-10 daily

 Pain above 3/10 = stay at current level

 Don't progress until pain is below 2/10 for at least 3-4 days

 If pain persists above 5/10 - go back one step

 Document your progress - this motivates and reveals patterns

 
 

 
 Important Principle

 Weaning is not about tolerating pain - it's about giving the tissue time to adapt. Patience is crucial for success.

Bekkenløsning vs. bekkenløsning

 

 Mange bruker "bekkenløsning" som et samlebegrep, men det finnes faktisk to ulike tilstander som krever forskjellig tilnærming. Les mer om dette i var artikkel om SI-ledd og bekkensmerter.

 
 Bekkenløsning (bekkenleddsmerter)

 Dette er den vanligste varianten under graviditet og skyldes at hormonet relaxin gjør leddbéndene i bekkenet mer elastiske. Kroppen forbereder seg på fødselen, men den Økte bevegeligheten kan gi smerter.

 
 Diffuse, ofte tosidige smerter foran i bekkenet (over symfysen)

 "Vaggegange"

 Rundt 20% av gravide får plagsomme bekkenleddsmerter

 
 

 
 Bekkenløsning (iliosakralleddsdysfunksjon)

 Her er problemet det motsatte - ett eller flere ledd i bekkenet har nedsatt bevegelighet.

 
 Ofte ensidig, skarp smerte bak i bekkenet

 Typisk lokalisert til ett iliosakralledd

 Smerten kan stråle til sete, lyske eller lær

 
 

 
 Hvorfor er dette viktig?

 Behandlingen er forskjellig. Ved bekkenløsning fokuserer jeg på stabiliserende Øvelser, mens bekkenløsning ofte responderer godt på leddmobilisering.

Describe symptoms for Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Symptoms

 Symptoms in Unilateral Hypofunction

 Symptom 
 Prevalence 

 Chronic dizziness 
 98% 

 Imbalance/unsteadiness 
 81% 

 Worsening with head movements 
 75% 

 Oscillopsia (unstable vision during movement) 
 22-70% 

 Fatigue/exhaustion 
 68% 

 Symptoms in Bilateral Hypofunction

 Bilateral hypofunction gives a characteristic symptom triad
 1. Unsteadiness When Walking and Standing

 The main complaint, especially on uneven surfaces, in darkness or with head movements. Many describe feeling like they're "walking on a boat."

 2. Oscillopsia - When the World Jumps

 Often the most bothersome symptom. The visual image "jumps" with head movements. About 70% experience this.

 3. Symptom-Free at Rest

 Symptoms disappear when you sit or lie still. This distinguishes bilateral hypofunction from other causes.

 4. No Spinning Dizziness

 Rarely classic vertigo because both sides are equally weak - there is no imbalance creating the sensation of rotation.

 Red Flags - When You Must Seek Medical Help Immediately

 Call emergency services or go to the emergency room immediately for
 Acute dizziness combined with headache, neck pain or recent trauma

 Speech difficulties, swallowing difficulties or unclear speech

 Paralysis, numbness or weakness in face, arm or leg

 Double vision or visual field loss

 Altered consciousness or confusion

 Up to 25% of acute dizziness cases at the emergency room may be caused by stroke in the posterior brain circulation.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Temporalisarteritt.

Hva er temporalisarteritt?: Temporalisarteritt er en autoimmun betennelsessykdom der immunsystemet angriper veggen i mellomstore og store arterier. Sykdommen kalles også kjempecellearteritt (GCA) fordi man ved vevsprøve finner karakteristiske kjempeceller (flerkjernede kjempeimmunceller) i den betente arterieveggen.

Hvorfor er dette så alvorlig?: Temporalisarteritt er den vanligste formen for vaskulitt (blodårebetennelse) hos eldre, og det er en av svært få hodepineårsaker som kan gi permanent, irreversibelt synstap .

Symptomer du MÅ kjenne til: Symptombildet ved temporalisarteritt er ofte karakteristisk, men kan variere. Noen pasienter har klassiske symptomer, mens andre presenterer med mer uspesifikke plager. Kjennskap til symptomene er avgjørende for tidlig oppdagelse.

Hvem rammes av temporalisarteritt?: Temporalisarteritt har et tydelig demografisk mønster som gjør det enklere å identifisere risikopasienter.

Sammenheng med polymyalgia revmatika: Temporalisarteritt og polymyalgia revmatika (PMR) er nært beslektede tilstander som ofte opptrer sammen. 40-60% av pasienter med GCA har samtidig PMR , og omtrent 10-15% av pasienter med PMR utvikler GCA.

Røde flagg - Når du MÅ til legevakt: Følgende symptomer hos personer over 50 år krever umiddelbar medisinsk vurdering. Ikke vent - ring legevakten eller 113.

Diagnostikk: Diagnosen temporalisarteritt baseres på en kombinasjon av kliniske funn, blodprøver og spesialundersøkelser. Viktigst: Behandling startes ved klinisk mistanke - man venter IKKE på bekreftende prøver.

Behandling: Behandling av temporalisarteritt er tidskritisk og livslang . Rask oppstart med kortison er det viktigste tiltaket for å forebygge synstap.

Kiropraktorens rolle - Gjenkjenne og henvise: Kiropraktorens rolle ved temporalisarteritt er utelukkende å gjenkjenne symptomene og sørge for akutt henvisning . Det finnes ingen form for manuell behandling, manipulasjon eller annen kiropraktisk intervensjon som er aktuell for denne tilstanden.

Describe Conditions Where Evidence Is Weak for When Orthotics Actually Help.

Conditions Where Evidence Is Weak

 

 For the following conditions, evidence is weak or absent - despite orthotics being frequently prescribed:

 
 "Overpronation"

 Nielsen et al. (2013) randomized 927 novice runners to shoes based on foot type versus neutral shoes. Result: No difference in injury rates. Overpronation as a diagnosis lacks scientific basis.

 Read more about the overpronation myth

 

 
 Flexible Flat Foot Without Symptoms

 Choosing Wisely (2023): "Avoid treatment of the normal variant asymptomatic flexible flat foot." Up to 26% of adults have flat feet - most without complaints. Treatment is unnecessary and potentially harmful.

 

 
 Nonspecific Foot and Heel Pain

 Whittaker et al. (2018) meta-analysis: Orthotics are no better than placebo in the long term. APTA (2023) does NOT recommend orthotics as isolated treatment for plantar fasciitis.

 

 
 Knee, Hip or Back Pain

 72-93% of podiatrists prescribe orthotics for these conditions - despite no evidence for effect. This represents significant overtreatment.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 50-year-old female with dizziness triggered by neck rotation. No spontaneous nystagmus. Negative Dix-Hallpike. No hearing loss. Neck pain and reduced ROM. Dizziness is brief (<30 sec) and always related to neck movement.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this dizziness is cervical and NOT central:
- Triggered only by neck movement (cervicogenic pattern)
- Negative Dix-Hallpike (rules out BPPV)
- No spontaneous nystagmus (central pathology often causes spontaneous nystagmus)
- Brief (<30 sec) and REPRODUCIBLE with neck rotation
- No hearing loss (rules out Meniere)
- Absence of central signs: no diplopia, no dysarthria, no dysphagia, no ataxia

Central dizziness (vertebrobasilar insufficiency):
- Would cause additional symptoms (5 Ds: dizziness, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, drop attacks)
- Would be UNPROVOKED or with specific head positions

Clinical picture: Cervicogenic dizziness.

Safe to treat with cervical mobilization, vestibular rehabilitation, exercises.

Explain treatment — exercise vs. surgery for Rotator Cuff — Complete Guide to the Rotator Cuff.

Treatment — exercise vs. surgery

 Research on rotator cuff treatment has changed dramatically over the last 10-15 years. Norway has been at the forefront of this development. 

 Exercise as first-line treatment

 For degenerative (atraumatic) rotator cuff injuries — which make up the vast majority — structured exercise is the first-line treatment. Several high-quality studies support this
 Norwegian research: Moosmayer et al.

 Stefan Moosmayer and colleagues at Oslo and Lovisenberg conducted a randomised controlled trial comparing exercise with surgery for small and medium-sized rotator cuff tears. Results after 1 year showed no significant difference between the groups (Kukkonen et al., 2015, Bone Joint J).

 Even more impressively: at 10-year follow-up (Moosmayer et al., 2019) there was still no clinically meaningful difference. The exercise group did just as well as the surgery group in the long term.

 The OPTIROT study (ongoing)

 OPTIROT is a large Norwegian randomised study comparing exercise with surgery for small and medium-sized tears. The study is led from Oslo and Lovisenberg and is one of the most important ongoing studies in the field internationally.

 Re-tear after surgery: 20-40%

 An important point that is often under-communicated: 20-40% of surgically repaired rotator cuff tears re-tear (Carr et al., 2015, Lancet). For large and massive tears, the re-tear rate is even higher. Interestingly, many patients have good function despite re-tear — which raises the question of whether it is the rehabilitation itself, rather than the tendon healing, that produces results.

Explain treatment for IT Band Syndrome.

Treatment

 Modern treatment focuses on hip strengthening rather than just stretching
 Hip Strengthening (Most Important!)

 Side-lying hip abduction: 3 sets x 15 reps

 Clamshells: With resistance band

 Single-leg squat: Focus on knee control

 Side plank: For lateral core stability

 Monster walks: With band around ankles

 Activity Modification

 Reduce running volume temporarily

 Avoid downhill and cambered surfaces

 Cross-train with swimming or cycling (if pain-free)

 Gradual return based on symptoms

 What About Stretching?

 The IT Band Can't Really Be Stretched

 The IT band is extremely strong fascia - it would take about 2000 lbs of force to stretch it 1%.
 Traditional IT band stretches likely work on other structures. Foam rolling may help with temporary
 pain relief but doesn't address the underlying cause.

T4 Syndrome

 Dysfunction in the upper thoracic spine that can cause radiation to arms and hands, often together with numbness or tingling. Usually responds well to manipulation.

Gi rådgiving om tilbake-til-arbeid etter akutt lumbago.

Tilbake-til-arbeid plan - Akutt Lumbago

Prinsipp: Tidlig, gradvis tilbakegang til arbeid gir bedre prognose enn langvarig sykemelding.

Uke 1 (Akuttfase):
- Sykemelding 100% ved behov (maks 3-5 dager anbefalt)
- Oppretthold daglige aktiviteter etter toleranse
- Unngå sengehvile >24 timer
- Korte gåturer 10-15 min x 3-4 daglig

Uke 2 (Gradert tilbakegang):
- Gradert sykemelding 50% hvis mulig
- Kortere arbeidsdager (4-5 timer)
- Hyppige stillingsendringer
- Bruk hev-senk pult

Uke 3-4 (Opptrapping):
- Øk til 75-100% arbeidstid
- Tilrettelegging: Unngå tunge løft, langvarig sitting
- Fortsett øvelser daglig

Tilrettelegging fra arbeidsgiver:
- Hev-senk pult
- Mulighet for å variere arbeidsstilling
- Fritak fra tunge løft i overgangsperiode
- Fleksibel arbeidstid ved behov

Viktig: Smerte betyr ikke skade. Det er trygt å jobbe med moderate smerter. Gradvis eksponering er bedre enn full unngåelse.

Hva forårsaker Morton's Nevrom?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Trange sko med smal taboks - hovedÅrsak

 Repetert kompresjon av nerven mellom mellomfotsbeina under gange forårsaker mikrotraumer, påfølgende fibrose og demyelinisering. Biomekaniske studier viser at høye heler flytter 28% av kroppsvekten til forfoten i flate sko, mot hele 66% i høye heler.

 Andre risikofaktorer

 
 Hallux valgus (bunion): Opptil 80% av pasienter med Morton's nevrom har samtidig hallux valgus

 Hammertar og andre tadeformiteter: Skaper baktrykk mot forfoten

 Platfot og hulfot: Assosiert med endret forfotmekanikk (se også tibialis posterior tendinopati)

 Sport og aktivitet: Loping, ballett, tennis, ski og klatring - disse aktivitetene kan også gi akillestendinopati eller stressfraktur

Explain treatment of trigger points for Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

Treatment of trigger points

 Trigger points respond well to manual treatment. The most important methods
 Effective treatment methods

 Ischemic compression: Sustained pressure on trigger point until it releases

 Dry needling: Thin needle into trigger point to release it

 Soft tissue treatment: Massage and friction to increase circulation

 Stretching: Muscle stretches to normalize length

 Heat: Improves circulation and eases tension

 Treatment at . Thorough examination

 Identify active and latent trigger points, rule out other causes like nerve entrapment or tendon
 disease.

 2. Manual treatment Main treatment 

 Combination of ischemic compression, soft tissue treatment and stretching to deactivate trigger points.

 3. Self-treatment

 Training in self-massage with tennis ball or Theracane, plus specific stretching and strengthening
 exercises.

 4. Cause correction

 Identify and correct factors that triggered the trigger points - ergonomics, loading patterns, stress.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Stressnakke og Triggerpunkter.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hva er sammenhengen mellom stress og nakkesmerter?

 Stress aktiverer kroppens kamp-eller-flukt-respons som Økermuskelspenning, særlig i nakke og skuldre. Kronisk stress fører til vedvarende muskelspenning som skaper triggerpunkter og smerter.

 

 
 Hva er triggerpunkter?

 Triggerpunkter er hypersensitive områder i muskler som føles som harde knuter. De kan gi lokal smerte og referert smerte til andre områder - for eksempel kan triggerpunkter i nakken gi hodepine.

 

 
 Hvordan behandles stressnakke?

 Behandling kombinerer manuell terapi (triggerpunktbehandling, mobilisering, massasje), Øvelser for styrke og bevegelighet, ergonomisk rådgivning, og stressmestringsteknikker.

 

 
 Kan jeg løse triggerpunkter selv?

 Ja, selvmassasje med tennisball eller foam roller kan hjelpe. Legg ballen mellom skulderblad og vegg, og rull forsiktig over omme punkter. Hold trykket på omme punkter i 30-60 sekunder.

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar det å bli kvitt stressnakke?

 Akutte symptomer kan lindres på 1-3 behandlinger. Varig bedring krever ofte 4-8 uker med behandling kombinert med Øvelser og livsstilsendringer.

Describe Is It C5-C6 Disc Herniation or Carpal Tunnel Syndrome? for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Is It C5-C6 Disc Herniation or Carpal Tunnel Syndrome?

 

 This is one of the most important questions to clarify, because the treatment is very different. Both
 conditions cause numbness in the fingers, but the causes and patterns are different.

 
 
 
 Characteristic
 C5-C6 Herniation (C6 Radiculopathy)
 Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
 
 
 
 
 Numbness
 Thumb and index finger
 Thumb, index finger, middle finger, half of ring finger
 
 
 Pain location
 Neck, shoulder, arm
 Wrist, palm
 
 
 Worsened by
 Neck movements, Spurling's test
 Repetitive hand work, bent wrist at night
 
 
 Relieved by
 Arm over head (Bakody's sign)
 Shaking the hand (Flick sign)
 
 
 Weakness
 Biceps, wrist extension
 Thumb grip (thenar atrophy in severe cases)
 
 
 Worst when
 Morning, after static neck position
 At night, early morning
 
 
 

 
 Double Crush Syndrome

 In some cases, you can have both conditions simultaneously. The nerve can be irritated both in the
 neck and at the wrist. This is called "double crush syndrome" and requires treatment of both locations
 for optimal recovery.

 

 Other Conditions to Rule Out

 
 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 The nerve is compressed between neck muscles and ribs. Symptoms can be similar, but often worsen when
 raising the arm overhead (opposite of Bakody's sign).

 

 
 Shoulder Pathology

 Rotator cuff injuries or impingement can cause radiation to the arm. Shoulder mobility is usually
 normal with pure neck problems.

Explain prognosis for Sinus Headache or Migraine?.

Prognosis

 Migraine

 Migraine is a chronic neurological condition that varies throughout life for most people. Many experience fewer attacks with age, especially women after menopause.

 Correct diagnosis is crucial - when patients who were misdiagnosed with sinusitis received migraine treatment, nearly 70% experienced improvement.

 Relapse is common and expected. The goal is to reduce attack frequency and severity, not necessarily to eliminate symptoms completely. For persistent daily symptoms, see chronic daily headache .

 Sinusitis

 Acute viral sinusitis resolves on its own. Bacterial sinusitis treated with antibiotics has a good prognosis. Some develop chronic sinusitis (over 12 weeks), which requires evaluation by an ENT specialist.

Describe What is the difference between tension headache and migraine? in the context of Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

What is the difference between tension headache and migraine?

 Migraine is often one-sided and pulsating, worsens with physical activity, and typically comes with nausea and both light and sound sensitivity. Tension headache is bilateral, pressing/tightening, does not worsen with activity, and rarely causes nausea.

Explain exercises at the desk for Shoulder.

Exercises at the Desk

 These simple exercises can be done sitting at the desk or standing beside it. They only take 30-60
 seconds each
 1. Shoulder rolls

 Roll your shoulders backward in large circles. Start by raising your shoulders toward your ears, then
 pull them back, down and forward again. Repeat 10 times.

 30 seconds 

 2. Neck stretch

 Gently tilt your head to one side (ear toward shoulder). Hold for 15-20 seconds. Repeat on the other
 side. Don't rotate your head, just side bending.

 40 seconds 

 3. Chest opening

 Lean back in the chair, open your arms out to the sides and push your chest forward. Squeeze your
 shoulder blades together. Hold for 10 seconds, repeat 3 times.

 30 seconds 

 4. Shoulder blade squeeze

 Pull your shoulder blades together as if trying to hold a pencil between them. Hold for 5 seconds,
 release. Repeat 10 times.

 50 seconds 

 5. Chin tuck

 Pull your chin straight back (double chin movement) while looking straight ahead. Hold for 5 seconds.
 This counteracts forward head posture. Repeat 10 times.

 50 seconds 

 6. Arms overhead

 Stretch both arms straight up above your head. Breathe in, stretch as high as you can. Breathe out,
 lower your arms. Repeat 5 times.

 30 seconds 

 Make this a habit

 Choose 2-3 of the exercises and do them every time you take a micro-break. Over time it becomes
 automatic, and your shoulders will thank you.

Describe Is It the Neck, Ear, or Brain? for Whiplash and Dizziness.

Is It the Neck, Ear, or Brain?

 

 This is perhaps the most important question to answer. Cervicogenic dizziness (neck dizziness) is a diagnosis of exclusion - other causes must first be ruled out.

 
 Signs of Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck)

 
 Dizziness increases with neck movements or when sitting still for long periods

 Feels like "swaying" or "unsteadiness" - not spinning

 You have concurrent neck pain

 Dizziness lasts minutes to hours (not seconds)

 Negative Dix-Hallpike test

 
 

 
 Signs of BPPV (Crystal Disease)

 
 Spinning vertigo lasting seconds to under one minute

 Triggered by specific head positions (turning in bed, looking up)

 Positive Dix-Hallpike test

 Not necessarily neck pain

 
 

 
 Signs of Concussion

 
 Problems with memory or concentration

 Light or sound sensitivity

 "Foggy" feeling in the head

 Becomes dizzy from screens or busy environments

 
 

 
 Important

 In car accidents, up to 40% may have both whiplash and concussion simultaneously. Then both must be treated.

 Characteristic Presentation

Describe diagnosis for Dysautonomia.

Diagnosis

 Active Standing Test

 The simplest test: measure heart rate and blood pressure lying down, then after 2, 5, and 10 minutes in a standing position. A heart rate increase of 30 beats/min or more without significant blood pressure drop raises suspicion of POTS. This test can be performed at a GP's office or by a chiropractor.

 Tilt-Table Test

 The gold standard for POTS diagnosis. The patient is secured to a table that tilts to 60-70 degrees, with continuous monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure for up to 45 minutes. Available at larger hospitals.

 Blood Tests and Exclusion

 Thyroid disease, adrenal insufficiency, anemia, and other conditions that can produce similar symptoms must be ruled out. ECG and possibly Holter monitoring exclude primary heart disease.

 When should you suspect dysautonomia?

 Dizziness that consistently worsens upon standing

 Heart palpitations without known heart disease

 Pronounced fatigue without explanation after standard workup

 Symptom worsening in heat, after meals, or with prolonged standing

 Symptoms that started after a viral infection (including COVID-19)

 Red Flags - Seek medical help immediately for
 Repeated fainting without warning

 Fainting during physical exertion

 Chest pain with breathing difficulties

 Rapidly progressing neurological symptoms

 Seizures in connection with fainting

 Call emergency services for acute, severe symptoms.

What is the prognosis for Dizzy When Lying Down? What You Need to Know About BPPV?

Prognosis

 

 
 With treatment: The outlook is generally very good. Over 90% achieve complete symptom relief with proper treatment. Many notice significant improvement immediately after the repositioning maneuver.

 

 
 Without treatment

 BPPV often resolves on its own, but it takes time: only 4% are better after one week, 18% after one month, and 51% after one year. Given how bothersome the condition is, treatment provides significantly faster improvement.

 

 
 Recurrence

 It's important to be prepared that BPPV can return:

 
 10-18% have recurrence within one year

 About 22% within five years

 Up to 50% over 10 years

 
 Higher risk of recurrence is seen in people with migraine, diabetes, high blood pressure, osteoporosis, and vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D supplementation can significantly reduce recurrence risk.

Clinical summary of Neurological Effects of Manual Therapy: What Research Shows.

Key takeaways

 Spinal manipulation affects nervous system function - not just the joints. Brain activity changes measurably after treatment (Lelic et al. 2016, n=24)

 Muscle strength may increase by approximately 16% after a single treatment session through altered cortical motor control (Haavik et al. 2018, n=28)

 Limitation: Most studies are small (n=20-40) and measure short-term effects. More research is needed

Describe What can the chiropractor do? for Scheuermann's Disease.

What can the chiropractor do?

 

 We must be honest about the evidence base: There are currently no randomized controlled
 trials on chiropractic treatment specifically for Scheuermann's disease. The available
 research consists of case reports.

 That does not mean treatment is without value. Based on clinical experience and general back
 research, chiropractic treatment can contribute to:

 
 Chiropractic Treatment Can Contribute To

 
 Improved mobility in stiff thoracic segments

 Reduction of muscle tension and trigger points

 Improved rib movement and breathing mechanics

 Pain relief through joint mobilization

 Guidance on exercises and ergonomics

 Functional improvement even if structure remains

 
 

 
 Important Expectation Management

 Chiropractic treatment can NOT "straighten out" a structural kyphosis in adults. The goal
 is symptom relief and better function, not structural change.

 

 Treatment Course

 For adults with symptomatic Scheuermann's disease, a typical course will involve a trial
 period of 6-8 treatments over 4-6 weeks to assess response. Most who respond to treatment
 experience improvement in pain and function within this period. With good response,
 maintenance treatment with 4-8 week intervals may be useful for some.

 Response varies significantly from person to person. Some have good and lasting effect,
 others experience only short-term relief, and some do not respond noticeably. An honest
 evaluation after the trial period is importan...

Describe causes and risk factors for Meralgia Paresthetica.

Causes and risk factors

 Common causes

 Tight clothing - pants, belts, corsets, spandex

 Obesity - fatty tissue puts pressure on the nerve

 Pregnancy - growing abdomen and hormonal changes (see also pelvic pain in pregnancy )

 Prolonged standing - increases stretch on the nerve

 Diabetes - makes nerves more vulnerable

 Surgery/trauma - in the pelvic or groin area

 Mechanical causes

 Tool belts - police equipment, carpenter belts

 Car seats - seat belt pressure on long drives

 Sports equipment - cycling shorts, climbing harnesses

 Hip surgery - positioning during surgery

 Medical causes

 Diabetes mellitus - 7 times increased risk

 Ascites - fluid in the abdomen

 Pelvic tumor - rare, but must be ruled out

 Scoliosis or pelvic asymmetry - can also cause SI
 joint problems 

 Note for diabetes

 Diabetics have 7 times increased risk for meralgia paresthetica

 Poor blood sugar control damages nerves in general

 With diabetes and MP - check blood sugar control

Assess red flags: 30-year-old male with low back pain, stiff in morning for about 20 minutes. Improves with movement. Worsens after prolonged sitting. No night pain. Normal blood work.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this is NOT inflammatory back pain (ankylosing spondylitis):
- Morning stiffness 20 min = under the 30-minute threshold for inflammatory
- Inflammatory back pain (ASAS criteria): morning stiffness >30 min, improves with activity, NIGHT PAIN
- No night pain (important criterion)
- Normal blood work (CRP, ESR would typically be elevated)
- "Improves with movement" is also common in mechanical pain
- Worsens after sitting = discogenic/mechanical pattern

Clinical picture: Mechanical low back pain with brief morning stiffness.

Safe to treat conservatively.

What is GTPS?: GTPS (Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome) is an umbrella term for pain on the outside
 of the hip around the greater trochanter - the bony prominence you can feel on the outside of your hip.
 It is one of the most common forms of hip pain .

Causes and Risk Factors: The gluteal tendons become compressed against the greater trochanter in certain positions and
 movements
Symptoms: With GTPS, the pain is typically located on the outside of the hip. Pain in the
 groin more often indicates problems inside the hip joint ( osteoarthritis , labrum tear , FAI ). Pain in the buttock region may be
 sciatica or piriformis syndrome .

Diagnosis: The diagnosis is primarily made clinically through history and physical examination.

Treatment: The most important study on GTPS treatment is the LEAP study (Mellor et al., BMJ
 2018), which compared exercise, cortisone, and "wait and see".

Prognosis: GTPS is a condition that takes time to treat - typically 6-9 months for full recovery.
 But the prognosis is good if you are patient and follow an exercise program.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Løperkne (PFPS) - Slik returnerer du til full distanse.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hva er hofte-paradokset?

 Hofte-paradokset beskriver hvordan svak hoftemuskulatur kan forårsake knesmerter. Når hofteabduktorene er svake, faller kneet innover ved hvert steg, noe som overbelaster patellofemoralleddet. Løsningen er å styrke hoften.

 

 
 Kan jeg fortsette å løpe?

 Ofte ja, men med justeringer. Reduser distanse og intensitet til et nivå der smerten er under 3/10. Mange har nytte av å Økestegfrekvensen med 5-10%.

 

 
 Hvor lang er rehabiliteringstiden?

 De fleste ser bedring innen 6-12 uker med riktig behandling. 40% har noe plager etter 1 Ør, men dette betyr ikke at de ikke kan løpe- bare at full symptomfrihet kan ta tid.

 

 
 Hjelper innleggssåler?

 Forskningen er blandet. Noen får nytte, spesielt ved overpronasjon, men de er ikke førstelinjebehandling. Hoftestyrke og løpeformjusteringer har bedre dokumentert effekt.

 

 
 Bør jeg bytte sko?

 Sko bør våre komfortable, men det finnes ingen "beste" sko for løperkne. Hvis skoene er slitt (over 600-800 km), er det lurt å bytte. Unngå drastiske endringer i demping/dropp.

 

 
 Hva med knebénd/patella-tape?

 Kan gi kortvarig symptomlindring hos noen, men løsninger ikke de underliggende Årsakene. Bruk gjerne som supplement, men ikke som erstatning for trening.

Describe causes of dizziness in elderly for Dizziness in Elderly and Fall Risk.

Causes of Dizziness in Elderly

 BPPV - 20-46% of Cases

 By far the most common cause of dizziness in elderly. Small calcium crystals become dislodged in the inner ear and disturb balance signals. Typically causes brief, intense dizziness with head movements.

 In elderly, symptoms may be less typical. Many experience only general unsteadiness rather than the classic "carousel feeling." Therefore, the condition is often overlooked.

 Medication Side Effects

 Many elderly take 5-10 different medications daily. The side effects - or combination of them - are a frequent cause of dizziness. The worst offenders include
 Blood pressure medications (can cause too low pressure when standing)

 Sleep medications and sedatives

 Antidepressants

 Diuretics

 Multisensory Deficits

 Balance depends on three systems: vision, balance organ, and sensation in the feet. With age, all three weaken slightly. Cataracts reduce vision, hair cells in the inner ear gradually die (presbyvestibulopathy), and nerve signals from the feet are slower.

 Orthostatic Hypotension

 Blood pressure drop when standing up. Common in elderly, especially those taking blood pressure medications.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Persistent Symptoms After Concussion.

What is Post-Concussion Syndrome?: Post-Concussion Syndrome (PCS) occurs when symptoms after a concussion persist longer than expected. In medical terminology, the condition is defined as symptoms lasting more than 3 months after a mild traumatic brain injury. PCS is one of several causes of persistent dizziness and can resemble other vestibular conditions.

Symptoms: Often located in the back of the head, worsens with bending or exertion.

Who is Most at Risk?: Women have 2-3 times higher risk of PCS than men. Adult women have an odds ratio of 2.57 for elevated symptom burden.

Types of Dizziness After Concussion: Here, small calcium crystals have loosened from their normal position in the balance organ and ended up in the semicircular canals. Post-traumatic BPPV often behaves differently than regular BPPV - it more often affects multiple canals simultaneously and can be more resistant to treatment.

Treatment: The latest international consensus (Amsterdam 2022) has turned previous treatment advice upside down. Complete rest is outdated and can actually prolong symptoms.

Prognosis - What Can You Expect?: The good news: Most people with PCS improve over time, especially with proper treatment.

Explain hip mobility exercises for Hip Exercises and Pelvic Training.

Hip mobility exercises

 Mobility exercises restore range of motion in the hip joint and reduce stiffness. Do these daily, ideally as a morning routine. All exercises should be performed at a calm pace without pushing through pain.

 1. Knee-to-chest

 Lie on your back with both knees bent and feet flat on the floor

 Grasp one knee and gently pull it toward your chest

 Hold for 30 seconds - feel the stretch in the buttock region and lower back

 Repeat on the other side

 2 repetitions per side

 Great exercise for loosening a stiff hip in the morning. Stretches hip flexors and lower back simultaneously.

 2. Supine hip rotations

 Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat

 Let both knees drop gently to one side in a controlled manner

 Hold for 2-3 seconds, then move them calmly to the opposite side

 Repeat 10 times to each side

 Mobilizes both the hip and lower back. Keep your shoulders on the floor throughout the movement.

 3. Butterfly stretch

 Sit on the floor with a straight back

 Place the soles of your feet together and let your knees drop to the sides

 Gently press your knees down with your elbows

 Hold for 30 seconds, breathe calmly

 2-3 repetitions

 Stretches the adductors (inner thigh). Avoid pushing your knees too far down - stop where it feels comfortable.

 4. Figure-4 stretch

 Lie on your back, cross one ankle over the opposite knee

 Grasp behind the lower thigh and gently pull toward your chest

 Feel a deep stretch in the buttock region

 Hold for 30 seconds per side

 2 repetitions per side

 Stretches the piriformis and deep external rotators. Note: Avoid this exercise with GTPS - adductor compression over the trochanter can worsen the condition.

 Mobility dosing

 Frequency: Daily, ideally morning and evening

 Duration: 30 seconds hold per stretch, 2-3 repetitions

 Intensity: Comfortable stretch, no pain above 3-4/10

 Time: Approximately 5-8 minutes total

What causes Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and risk factors

 

 Over 90% of golfer's elbow cases are caused by work-related factors - not golf. The most
 common causes are:

 
 Repetitive manual work Most common

 Manual labor like carpentry, plumbing, painting. Repetitive gripping and twisting movements over time.
 

 

 
 Office work

 Prolonged mouse and keyboard use, especially with poor ergonomics. Often combined with tennis elbow.
 See our article on mouse arm.

 

 
 Throwing sports

 Baseball, handball, javelin throwing. Repetitive throwing motions strain the inside of the elbow.

 

 
 Golf (5-10% of cases)

 Actually only a small proportion. Most common in beginners with incorrect technique.

 

 Important risk factors

 
 Repetitive gripping movements: Same movement thousands of times

 Heavy lifting with bent wrist: Increases strain on the inside

 Vibration: Use of vibrating tools (drill, grinder)

 Age 40-60 years: Natural aging of tendon tissue

 Smokers: Poorer blood supply to tendons

Differential diagnoses for Spondylosis?

Foraminal stenosis

 Can cause radiating pain, numbness, or weakness in the legs (radiculopathy). Occurs when the nerve openings between vertebrae narrow from osteophytes and disc height loss.

Central stenosis

 Can cause pain and heaviness in the legs when walking (neurogenic claudication). Occurs when the spinal canal itself becomes too narrow. Read more about spinal stenosis .

Prognose

 Kostokondritt har generelt god prognose. Over 90% av pasientene opplever symptomlindring innen 3-4 uker med konservativ behandling (StatPearls, 2024). De fleste tilfeller varer fra noen uker til 1-2 måneder.

 4% 
 tilbakefallsrisiko 

 50% 
 kan ha noe ubehag etter 1 år 

 Tilbakefallsrisiko: Studien av Disla et al. (1994) fant en tilbakefallsrate på kun 4% etter to ør. Dette er relativt lavt sammenlignet med mange andre muskuloskeletale tilstander.

 Langtidsprognose: Omtrent 50% av pasientene kan fortsatt ha noe ubehag etter 1 år, og ca. 33% har fortsatt ømhet ved palpasjon ved 12 måneders oppfølging (Medscape; Spalding et al., 2003). Kroniske eller behandlingsresistente tilfeller kan kreve vurdering hos revmatolog for å utelukke inflammatoriske sykdommer.

Beskriv symptomer ved c6-c7 prolaps for C6.

Symptomer ved C6-C7 prolaps

 Symptomene ved C6-C7 prolaps følger C7-nervens forsyningsområde og er ofte mer distinkte enn ved andre nivåer.

 Typiske C7-symptomer

 Smerte: Strøler fra nakke og skulder, ned baksiden av overarmen til langfingeren

 Nummenhet /prikking: Langfingeren er mest rammet, kan inkludere deler av peke- og ringfinger

 Svakhet: Triceps (vansker med å strekke albuen mot motstand), fingerfleksjon

 Refleksendring: Redusert eller fravårende tricepsrefleks

 Det klassiske smerteprofilen

 C7-radikulopati har et karakteristisk mønster
 Smertens forløp

 Starter ofte med nakkestivhet eller hodepine 

 Utvikler seg til skuldersmerte over dager til uker

 Strøler gradvis nedover armen til handen

 Nummenhet i fingre kommer gjerne sist

 Forverrende og lindrende faktorer

 Forverres typisk av
 Å vri hodet mot den affiserte siden

 Bakover-bøyning av nakken (ekstensjon)

 Hosting, nysing eller pressing

 Langvarig stillesitting med fremskutt hode

 Lindres typisk av
 Å legge handen på hodet (Bakody's tegn)

 Lett nakkebøyning fremover

Symptomer
